Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And bleeding of these veins is not easy access, unless by skill and experience; but easily in two others which pass over custom phlebotomy: which are under the skin.And their bleeding is done according to two modes.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Either pricking with a broad myrtle-wood phlebotomist; or olive oil to the subtlety of decline; or cut with a phlebotomy dagger, and it is Alnesil.Et si fit pungendo, sint venae ad latere externumque: et est utilitas illius in lueris et morbis, quae procedunt de humore sanguini.
Et haec est forma eius.	And if it is pricking, the veins are on the outside; and its use is in lueris and diseases that result from a humour of blood.And this is its form.Et si fit oliuando, facies ad laterem internum.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	And if it's olive oiling, make the face to the inner side.Thus is Alnesil, which suits the section.Et phlebotomia eius in lueribus et morbis.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And bleeding of these is in lueris and diseases.And from these are species broad, and subtle according to the amplitude of veins and strictness them Form phlebotomy myrtle be broad, as you see.Et sit subtilis, secundum necessitatem: nam si uena latior sit, facies eam subtilem; si quaeratur ad lueres et morbos, qui procedunt de humore sanguini.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And is necessary subtle, for if the vein is wider, make it subtle; if it is sought after lueris and diseases that result from a humour of blood.And suits to open veins hollow, full, proceeding, apparent, coarse, and those which contain coarse blood, turbid.Et si uena est stricta et profunda, facias eam latam: nam quaeratur ad phlebotomandas venas quae procedunt de humore sanguini.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this bloodletting instrument is smaller in width and has finer edges.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	It is suitable for letting blood from subtle veins that contain a subtle yellow blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	¶ On the bloodletting of the basilic vein.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	However, of these three veins, the basilic vein is the best instrument for bloodletting.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	For it draws blood from diseases which are under the throat and neck, from that which follows the chest, and the abdomen: and it suits a phlebotomist with a phlebotomy to beware, and be over fear because under it is an artery.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If therefore he makes a mistake, and adds to the puncture of the bloodletting, he will hit that artery, and there will be an occurrence of a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore it is necessary that the bloodletting not be done with a bloodletting instrument that is puncturing; rather let it be cut with an Alnesil.Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	Which if it does not appear with a manifest appearance of the Basilic, then it is necessary that you move away from it, and exchange it for another, or seek some branch of it: or bloodlet in its place the arm vein.Et si in brachio non apparet uenam, sed apparet in antebrachio, tunc oportet ut sanguinem eam extrahas in antebrachio: et ne facias phlebotomiam per puncturam, sed per secturas.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	And if it does not appear in the arm, but appears in the antebracio, then you must draw blood from it in the antebraccio: and do not make the bloodletting by puncture, but by incisions.For it is manifest, and cut it with the phlebotomy Anesil, as we have said.Et si in antebrachio non apparet uenam, sed apparit in manibus, tunc oportet ut sanguinem eam extrahas in manibus: et ne facias phlebotomiam per puncturam, sed per secturas.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	And if it does not appear in the antebraccio, but appears in the hands, then you must draw blood from it in the hands: and do not make the bloodletting by puncture, but by incisions.But if you wish to know the pulse of it, then before the tightening of the arm, touch the place until you recognize the location of the pulse.Et si non apparet pulsus per strkturam brachii, sed apparit in antebrachio vel manibus, tunc oportet ut sanguinem extrahas in antebrachio vel manibus: et ne facias per puncturam, sed per secturas.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark on the spot with cautery, afterwards on the arm, and cut the vein with a concave incision with a phlebotomist of Alnesil as we said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And be careful that the blow does not fall through space from the site of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see, as you tighten the ligament, a swelling at the site where you marked with cautery, then that swelling is an arterial swelling: therefore release it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	If you see the blood rise at the phlebotomy as the urine of a child and it is thin blood, red: then you know that it is from arterial blood.Et si uides eam sanguinem cadere in ligamen, et ligamen non continet eam, et tu scis quod non est sanguis arteriae: rubeus enim est et grossus.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	And if you see the blood fall on the ligament and the ligament does not contain it, and you know that it is not arterial blood: for it is red and thick.Then therefore hurry and put your finger over that space lengthwise, then remove your finger.Et si uides inflationem cadere et sanguinem cadere, tunc scias quia est ex sanguine arteriae.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If therefore the blood is cut off (for it is often cut off), then tighten the arm and let go of it; and let the feeble man beware of its movement, and let him be above his fear.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And do not move it for several days until he is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	But if the blood does not stop and you are overcome by it, then cut the artery if it is apparent to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its ends are clamped down upon and the blood cut off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take the bark of a fig tree and find it; take one half and tighten it around the spot with a bandage in a decent manner, with a ligature and little threads until the next day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if the blood is cut off, that is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not, then treat it with that from which its antecedent came by memory, and the blood flow is cut off from the spot of the powder; and the cutting off of its blood is not difficult in many dispositions, on account of the smallness of the wound and the possibility of the ligature from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	§ On the phlebotomy of the Dark Vein.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	Now the Dark Vein is subject to phlebotomy, because it draws blood from the upper part of the head and lower part of the body; for this reason, because it is composed out of the Basilic Vein and the Cephalica Vein, as we have said.Et ista trahit sanguinem ad medullam ossium: nam traxit sanguinem a parte superioris capitis, et ad partem inferioris per uenas quae in medullam ossium infunduntur.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it behooves the phlebotomist to be over that fear from his phlebotomy, for under it is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore he adds to the pricking of the phlebotomy, and finds a nerve, there ensues stupor on it, and its cure is difficult, and perhaps it is not cured entirely.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve oft-times appears in sense.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	But if it is hidden in certain men, and is subtle, and does not appear: then you must put your phlebotomy where you phlebotomize, the cut with Alnesil, and the avoiding of nerves with your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	If it is a vein between two nerves, then find the vein in length.Quidam dicunt: ponas phlebotomiam tuam prope sero.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	Some say: put your phlebotomy close to the ear.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	But as for phlebotomy of the Cephalic vein, it is for attracting blood from the head, and brings about diseases of the eyes.Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it behooves in this vein properly, if you will, to phlebotomize her by pricking with a olive-wood phlebotomy, or with a myrtle-wood phlebotomy: for it is safer of veins, because there is no artery under it, nor nerve.Et si pulsas eam cum mano tua, et pulseris eam cum phlebotomo, erga sero, non debes sedere sed statim debes ambulare, et pergere pedem tuum, donec ueniat ad meatus tuos, et ad articulus tuos.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	However, when you bleed a varicose vein, you must take only the head of the lizard and seek a gentler spot; and it will not hurt if it is not found with the first blow, so that you can return to it several times with bleeding.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	However, perhaps an abscess forms in some people when they are not bled on the first strike, but that abscess does them no harm either.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	On the benefits of bloodletting and the precautions to be observed in it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	Now as to the nature of bloodletting and its accidents, you must consider their correction.In phlebotomia enim si sanguis non egreditur, sed in venam recidit: apparet postea sub cutem tumescens, et rubicundum factum, et saepe mortuus est homo ex ea causa.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	First, then, you should know that bloodletting is not administered for the sake of curing illness, or its persistence, or as a precaution against the onset of disease.Cum enim fit phlebotomia in humore melancolico, et in tempo frigido: statim sequuntur post eam aduentus aegritudinum.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And when bloodletting is performed in a melancholic humour, and in cold weather: immediately afterwards the onset of diseases follows it.And let bloodletting be done in one of the three veins which are in the elbow, namely the Cephalic, and the Dark, and the Basilic.Et si sanguis phlebotomiae non egreditur per cutem: sed recidit in venam: apparet postea sub cutem tumescens, et rubicundum factum, et saepe mortuus est homo ex ea causa.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And so that bloodletting is performed at the beginning of Spring after fasting and also in Summer, Autumn and Winter after a meal when signs of repletion appear.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And let bloodletting be done on the first day or on the third day after three hours have passed from that day.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	Bloodletting which is administered for various ailments does not have a particular time determined for it; but whenever convenience and necessity demand it, it may be done at night or by day, at any hour, and at any time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not right that boys should be bled until they reach the age of fourteen years.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Nor let a pregnant woman be bled except from the fourth month to the seventh.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Nor let aged men who have already gone beyond sixty years be bled.Et non oportet sanguis aspirari per punctura venarum nisi a medico perito et optimo, et in loco ubi omnia sint parata ad curam.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When someone wants to bleed for any reason, they must cleanse their intestines beforehand with a gentle enema if there is a lot of constipation in them, so that the veins are not attracted by putrid superfluities from the intestines during bleeding, which harm the principal organs.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Neither let the patient bleed while fasting, that is, with a sense of nausea, nor after vomiting, nor after leaving drunkenness until it has left them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Nor the feeble with dropsy.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And beware of bleeding again after colic pain and vomiting, and abdominal flow, and multiplication of intercourse, and labor and exercise, and vigils, and fasting, and everything that dissolves strength from a physical or animal thing.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider in subtlety of the humors before it if there is blood thick with food and drink, and medicines, if possible for him.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then enter the bath, if something does not prohibit it, or exercise in some exercise so that the blood is subtle.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And put the bleeding of it in the chest around the third day, as we have said, and try to have the chest emptied of it on that day from all bad animal accidents: such as distress, anger, fear; and from all bodily accidents, such as labor, pain, excessive flow, and those like them.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And have present things with which the custom of men runs according to their use of aromaticity, and scent, and tripudiation, and the like by quantity of possibility.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then let the phlebotomist sit above the powder which is higher than the powder of bleeding; then he will draw out his arm and wipe it with his hand twice or three times.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then tie the vein with a ligature and wind it twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the constriction be moderate, because when it is unequal or by superfluity in constriction then it prohibits the course of blood; or in relaxation then it also prohibits the course of blood.Et si lygamen praeterit, tunc phlebotomator detrahat eam cum digitis suus.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the bandage has been applied, it is necessary that the person to be bled should rub his hands simultaneously up and down until the veins are dilated and become palpable.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the operator should wipe the site of the phlebotomy with a little old oil that is proper for this purpose.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he should place his left index finger above the vein at a point just beneath where he wishes to perform the phlebotomy, gently so as not to drive away the vein and break the incision.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	For there is in veins one that flees like a string at the time of phlebotomy; and there is also one that is full of blood; and when you place the phlebotomy upon it, it is drawn back under the phlebotomy, and thus deceives the operator who does not open up the vein; but if he opens it, it is tight, because of this the operator must be firm and attentive to all these things.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then remove the phlebotomy.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If therefore it opens one vein at first, then that is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then repeat on the same spot with another incision slightly below or above, if the site is not swollen.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	If it has become swollen, or feeble then leave him alone for a day, or two days and don't tie the ligature.Et in diebus sequentibus iteret ut supra.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps it is a hot boil.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	And he must not go into a bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then let him bleed, if he wishes.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	If the wound is small, or if the blood flows gently, and you are afraid that a quantity of blood will not flow out; then repeat the phlebotomy at the opening itself according to its straightness, and add little to the operation.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do this quickly, before the place is bled, for a bled place is in many people at the operation of little.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If you see that it is already bled then you shall by no means repeat over it, for it avails nothing with you.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And put over it something of the dung of oil, because it eases the flow of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And this is better in this place than oil itself and other oils.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And likewise put the dung of oil into all your phlebotomies, when you bleed veins at the prohibition of flow of blood; and they make this with alfarach tallow, and sagenia, when one of these is put over the place.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	For blood flows gently and dissolves when it is thick.Quod si post ea uenere sanguis quiescit: ita quaeratur ut adduxerit illum ad hanc quietem tyriaca, qui non possit perueniere ad sanguinem et eiectare ei, nisi adduxerit per aliam rationem.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	If blood stops after these things; then let it be sought out that tyriaca brought him to this quietness, who cannot reach the blood and cast it out unless through another reason.If it happens at a place of phlebotomy a large boil, for it often happens, especially to he who is not bled except through that vice, or if the opening of the vein is small, then hasten and put over the place a sponge infused in water and salt, gently heated; and compress it one hour: because it dissolves.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And it is necessary that you do this after the flow of blood from the vein itself, with its complement, or from another vein.Et si possis ponere super locum oleonorum faecem, et olfacere uigilia: faciunt illud cum sanguine uti tyriaca, qui post uenesectionem non habuit quietem, nam solutio ista multum adiuuat.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If it remains in place for a few days and turns black or green, it does no harm; if you like, put some aloe or dissolved Myrrh on it, or something of the juice of costmary, that is, calaminth, or similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And very often hematomas and bumps occur during bleeding basilic vein.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Therefore put your hand over it; then if you feel softness under your hand over it, that protuberance is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Therefore be careful to put on it something of what we have said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood will flow from it out of an artery.Quod si remanserit in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a plaster for her with that which has astringency, so that the place may harden.Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it with the rest of the treatment until it is healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary to draw blood from every person according to the quantity of his strength.Quod si non feceris, periculum est, ut moriatur.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And that which appears by a purple color above the blood.Nam si erit in medio sanguinis, fac eam cum eisdem.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then let it come out until it turns red; and likewise if you see it thick, then let it come out until it is thinned out; and likewise if it is sharp, then let it come out until its sharpness is taken away.Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.Nam si erit in medio sanguinis, fac eam cum eisdem.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for the person who is full and strong, and needs a bloodletting at once, that the incision of the vein be enlarged, and that the bleeding be wide; and in him who is weak, let it be the contrary.Quod si non feceris, periculum est, ut moriatur.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary to remove it with forceps and that there should be a tight opening; and the best method of administration for venesection is to make a transversal cut not a puncture wound.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this mode of phlebotomy is safe from blood flow and cutting of nerve; and is praiseworthy and safer than phlebotomy by breadth and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And he who is accustomed to experience fainting during phlebotomy, ought to eat some bread soaked in pomegranate juice or mulberry juice before phlebotomy if it has been warmed; and draw three or four times from his blood.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if he is of a cold complexsion then let him take before phlebotomy bread soaked in myrrh syrup or in aromatized honey syrup with spices or in aromatized fragrant syrup.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	If fainting occurs during phlebotomy and its cause is abundant blood flow then let him take a drink of meat water and fine fragrant syrup; and use an aromatic with saltpetre, and smear his chest with it; and use the other remedies we have described in the chapter on fainting due to discharge.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	But he who wants to treat his arm and remove his blood gently a second time; it is necessary for him whose phlebotomy is due to abundant discharge and his power is weak, to remove the blood gradually during continuous days because of the quantity of his power.Et si est uiribus debilis et non potest uenire ad phlebotomiam: oportet ut accipiat moxam aere in aqua calida, et potet eum, et postea faciat phlebotomiam.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	But if he who wants to treat his arm and remove his blood gently a second time, and his body is strong then let him do it after seven or nine hours from his first phlebotomy.Et si est corporis debilis, et non potest bene uenire ad phlebotomiam: oportet ut accipiat moxam aere in aqua calida, et potet eum, et postea faciat phlebotomiam.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wants to attract blood from his body to the opposite part to which it inclines must wait until the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	For those whose body has a lot of blood that is already heated and sharpens, causing fever, the blood must exit in its entirety and a large quantity must be extracted from it. The opening should be enlarged until fainting occurs: after you have observed all the conditions of phlebotomy, and placed your hand over his pulse in the path of the blood flow, so that death does not occur at the site of syncopis.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	Because many times it happens that when the phlebotomist is ignorant and careless, it falls.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And when you wish to dissolve the arm and dissolve blood again on the second day, after the opening of the vein has been closed, and the exit of the blood is difficult, you should not press upon it with vehemence, and quickly open it by making an incision.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	Because this is very bad, rather leave it until the second day of phlebotomy.Et si uolueris soluere brachium, et trahere sanguinem de corpore, post diem primum: facit te, ut sit super eum tuus digitus, et non recedat ab eum, donec soluatur brachium.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or remove with a sharp phlebotomy instrument that which has coagulated from blood at the opening of the vein, and place over it something dissolved salt in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And place over it some of the ointment known as alfaroc or sagenia, and place a light compression upon it until the blood comes out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If, however, the vein is already ulcerated, then leave it and do not cut it until the ulcer has healed.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	If need demands that blood be let a second time and there is no excuse for not doing so, then let the blood either with a phlebotomy instrument at the spot itself or on the other arm in another vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	The veins of the arm are phlebotomized at the spot of the Fusca and Basilica, when they cannot be found and are hidden, because it is a compound of those two.Et postea ponatur super apostematem salis dissoluti in aqua, et alfarochi tyriacum cum mirabilem, et balsamicum, et sanguis egredatur de apostematis, et uena non claudatur, sed sedata sit.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of this bleeding is that one weak places his hand in hot water until it becomes red by the heat and the vein appears clearly.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then let him tie a ligature not too tightly but with moderate tightness over it.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then let him bleed according to the crosswise method gradually, not latitudinally or according to its length; and let there be a wide opening, and let your bleeding with which you are bleeding be just above the joint of the hand.Et si transuertur sanguis in extremitatem digitus, et intraverit ligatura super iuncturam, et non possit extendi pedem ad summam, sed pedes ad summa sint subligati.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	And if the blood passes into the tip of the finger and the ligature has entered upon the joint, and he cannot extend his foot to the end, but let his feet be bound under him.If the exit of the blood is prohibited, then return the hand to hot water and let the blood run in the water until you obtain your desire.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	But if you are in the days of summer, then you are excused from returning the hand to hot water.Et quod si sanguis non currit cum primis phlebotomiis: sed si cuntis sanguis non currit, iterum intromittas manum in aquam calidum: et sicut antea facies usque ad necessitatem tuam, vel donec sanguis intruit ligaturas.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And if the blood does not run with the first bleeding; but if after all the blood does not run, return your hand to hot water and do as before until you obtain your desire, or until the blood enters the ligatures.And most often the running of blood in hot water takes place in wintertime.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And the bleeding of this vein is healthier than all veins because there is no throbbing vein or nerve beneath it.Et si in hac uena ueniat sanguis multum, quod multum debet essed ad summam pedem ut pedes subligantur cum ligatura, et non possunt ad summam pedem extendi: sed intromittas manum in aquam calidum usque ad necessitatem tuam.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	The phlebotomy of the right hand is a treatment for liver diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is that you tighten the vein of the hand with a ligature, or your own hand, after you have placed it in warm water until the vein swells and is clearly felt.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then perform the phlebotomy by pricking across it.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut it completely, that will do her no harm in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And be careful not to press your hand down with the phlebotomy.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	Beneath this are nerves of the fingers stripped of flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then return your hand to the warm water and let the blood flow in it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not return it to the warm water, the blood will coagulate at the opening of the vein and be prevented from flowing.Et conserua, ne tu demoves manum tuae sub aqua, sed dimitte in ea per uenas currere sanguinem, donec non sint ullum plus fluxus.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When you have extracted the amount of blood that is necessary, then put on oil and salt, so that it does not congeal quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And in the same way, you must do with every cut branch.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The sign of the bleeding from his left hand is that it pertains to diseases of the spleen; and similarly do the bleeding as you did in the second one equally.Et si uideris, quod sanguis non currit per ramum, sed stetit, adhaerebitque ad ramum, ut oportet, et non cursus est, ut debet: tu fac, ut disces de sanguine, quoniam non debet stetire.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The sign of bleeding from the saphenous vein is for diseases which are in the lower part of the body, as diseases of the uterus, and retention of the menses, and infirmities of the kidneys, and old ulcers of the buttocks and thighs, and similar diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of bleeding is that the sick person should put his foot into hot water and make friction over it until the veins become prominent, and tie a ligature above the junction of the foot with a strap.Et si ramus stetit, adhaereritque ad ramum, et sanguis non cursit per eum, ut debet: tu fac iterum incisionem in ramure, et intra te et ramum, et itere trahe sanguinem, donec per ramum cursu, sicut debet.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And indeed, the location of this vein is next to the heel bone and appears opposite the thumb; and many branches originate from it on the surface of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	So phlebotomy should be performed at its larger branch or next to the heel bone at its confluence; for it is better and safer.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	But if phlebotomy is performed on the surface of the foot, then beware of the nerves that are below it upon the surface of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And position your phlebotomy where you will phlebotomize across it as if you wish to pierce it; and let the phlebotomist be a Nesil.Et si perierit sanguis in eam, ut necesse est in talibus, stipe uenam illam, ne ad nervum ueniat: et trahe ad te eam in palpare.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	And if the blood does not flow out of it as it must do in such a case, then massage its leg in warm water; and let the blood run in it until it is relieved.But if its exit is blocked, then massage its leg in warm water; and let the blood run in it until it is relieved.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	But if the phlebotomist mistakes it on the first stab, then he should go a little higher with the phlebotomy, for its site is safe and you need not fear evil from this, when you beware of the nerves as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And similarly with the saphenous vein of the other leg likewise.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	But the site of the sciatic vein, as we have said, is next to the heel bone on the side of the shin.Et uenae Popliteae locus sub capite flexore genuae: et eorum rami multum intraunt ad pedem.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the site of the popliteal vein is under the head of the knee-bender; and its branches penetrate much into the foot. And the indication for its phlebotomy is, for pain in the ankle, when it is due to hot blood.Et si non est dolus ibi, sed caliditas, tunc facies pedem eum calidum a frigore, et stipe uenam illam et trahe ad te eam in palpare.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And its quality is such that the invalid should enter the bath and hurry out: and he should draw up his leg from the ankle to above the calf by four fingers with a long, fine ligature: for it would not be apparent without this.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When therefore it appears, then the phlebotomy is according to whatever method it is possible for you, or according to transversion; and it is better, either to cut it by an incision, or to cut it by a section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	For the place of it is more healthy, and it is in many persons very much concealed.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If you do not find it at all, and it does not appear to the senses at all; then phlebotomize some branch of it, and that is which appears on the back of the foot, and turned towards the ear: and beware of nerves, and let blood flow in a quantity as much as you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then loose the ligature, and place over the place of phlebotomy a piece of skin, and tie the place.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	For it is healed quickly.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	Of Ventousation, and the quality of its use.
Caput XCVIII.	Head 98.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	From horn, from bronze, and from bronze-tinted hide are made the tongs.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	Indeed the ventosa is made in two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	By bloodletting and by scarification; and there is another ventosa without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	Indeed the ventosa that is without scarification is made in two ways: by suction, and by compression.
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or it is with fire.Et Ventosatio quidem fiunt secundum octo modis.
Aut est absque igne.	Indeed ventosas are made according to eight ways: with or without fire, with or without scarification; and with or without bloodletting.Et sunt quidam qui uentosationem faciunt cum scarificatione et cum igni.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	There are fourteen places in the body where bloodletting is performed after making a superficial cut on the skin.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	One of them is the bloodletting of Alnocrati, and it is at the back of the head; and of Alkehel, and it is in the middle of the neck; and of the two blades of Alhagdahim, and they are two lamina in the neck from its two sides simultaneously; and of the two mental bloodlettings, and they are below the jaw on both sides of the lower lip; and of the two spatular bloodlettings; and of Alachosos, which is above the tip of the tail; and of the two axillary bloodlettings, and they are in the middle of the two arms; and of the two crural bloodlettings; and of the two femoral bloodlettings.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	Indeed, the bloodletting of Alnocrati will not draw blood from the minute veins scattered throughout the flesh, and because of this its power is not diminished, just as is the case with phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Bloodletting with or without fire should not be performed on any disease caused by fullness until the whole body has been emptied.Et si fit, non curat se ut per uentosationem aut igne cadant corpora, vel quod faciunt per lythotripsiam et phlebotomiam.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If necessity compels a bloodletting because of disease or habit, we perform it at any hour of the day, at the beginning, middle and end of the month.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	This is because there are people in whom blood multiplies until it needs to be extracted by bloodletting; they find a heaviness and pain in their head.Et ex eo quod sanguis est, cadunt uiri in somnum profundum, et exeo quod multum est, est memento de eius extractione.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And there are those who find swelling and redness on their face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And there are those who find itching on their face and forehead, darkness and dimness of sight.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And there are those who are affected with scabies.Et ex eis est qui inuenit rubedinem in oculis suis, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And there are those whose sight is impaired by redness, darkness and dimness. And there are those who suffer from excessive laughter.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And there are those who find a taste of blood in their mouth; or their tongue bleeds.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And there are those whose sleep is excessive.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And there are those who see in their dreams blood and redness, and the dead, and wounds, and things similar to these.Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo uentosationes et uberes, et quae sunt praeter naturam, et simulacra uirorum et mulierum.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	And when we see any of these things, and particularly if it is in the middle of the third month, then we command a blister to be made after two or three hours have passed of that day.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	Now the blister for the nape is: because it helps with weight on the head, and what is poured out to the eyes.Iuuamentum uentosationis super caput est: quoniam confert ad dolorem in facie et ad rubedinem oculorum.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	And it is fitting that this be after the evacuation of the whole body.Iuuamentum uentosationis est: quoniam confert ad dolorem in facie et ad rubedinem oculorum.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this is a ventouse for head bleeding.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it must not be used by those with a cold complexion or who have catarrh.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it does him great harm.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And therefore the old and those whose heads are subject to colds must not use it.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	But if you insist on using it constantly, you will suffer from forgetfullness.Et omnia quae super eam fiunt, fiunt cum obliuione et cum apoplexia.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And for that reason you should instruct your assistant to lower his hand with a cupped wind instrument a little below the area being treated, fearing an obliteration of the wound.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Ventose or Alkahal is a substitute for the Phlebotomy of the Black vein and the Phlebotomy of the Royal vein, and it causes breathlessness because of the constriction, and the crackling of the instrument, and coughing, and filling.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And you should push the Alkahal wind instrument a little, for if it is placed lower down it generates weakness of heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	However the ventose of alhagdahim, causes pains in the head and eye, and migraine and piercing pain, and pain in the roots of teeth; and is a substitute for the Royal Phlebotomy.Et oportet Ventosatorem, ut sit uir experiens et prudens et qui scit, quid agat, et praecipere eum medicus debet, ut ponat ventosas super loca dolentia secundum qualitatem doloris, quae in singulis locis uenerunt.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And you should instruct the person doing the cupping to apply the cupping glass on the painful areas according to the quality of pain in each area that has come about. And you should tell him not to press his hand when scarifying so he doesn't cut an artery and cause bleeding.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	However, the ventose under the chin causes alcohol in the mouth and corruption of the gums, and similar diseases in the mouth; and is a substitute for the phlebotomy of the other lips that are in two lips.Et propter illud oportet Ventosatorem, ut ponat super loca dolentia cuppulas, et uentosas super caput et cervicem, cum scarificatione: et sic facit, donec fluxum sanguinis desista.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	The application of spatulas brings relief from pain and heat in this case.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	The ventosas or suction cups on the interior parts of two fires bring about bloodletting from three veins, the Basilica, the Fusca and the Cephalica: because it draws blood out of all those minute vessels which are in the flesh; and these minute vessels draw it out of larger vessels until the attraction reaches the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And you must direct the operator of the ventosa not to go too far in making incisions, because there is flesh removed and underneath are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	The ventosa that suctions over the anus brings relief from hemorrhoids and sores below.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And you must direct the operator of the ventosa to use a large ventosa made of brass; for this part needs strong suction and fine ventosas may possibly be broken there; therefore it should be scarified deeply.Et praecipias Ventosatori, ut uentoset in ipso, quoniam est locus profusius sanguinis.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	Ventosae or wind-bound reduce the legs markedly because they attract blood from all over the body and cause ancient pains in kidneys, wombs, and bladder; they provoke menstrua and cause bothor and ademenul. They stand in place of phlebotomy of two saphenous and alhorcobeni.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	However, they weaken the body a lot and cause fainting to occur in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	And the wound of Alhorcobeni wind-bound is close to the wound of two leg wind-bound.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of the wind-bound is that you should place the wind-bound first empty and suck with a moderate suction; and do not prolong the position of the wind-bound, but put them quickly and move them quickly, so that the humors come to the place with equal approach: and do not cease to repeat it and continue, until you see the place already red and swollen, and the redness of blood appears. Then scarify, and repeat the suction gradually.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider the arrangement of the body.Et si uultis facere unam crurum Ventosam, facite eam in crure dextro: et ponite alhorcobeni Ventosam super genua, et manum sub ea, et sugate suctione plena: et postea remouet illum uelociter, ita ut non remoue manum, sed remouet corium per se: et iterato suctione donec uides rubedo sanguinis.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	And he who has tender flesh and few pores should be scarified only once, not more: so that the place does not become ulcerated.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And direct the cupping-glass attendant to enlarge the scarification, and not go very deep; and moderate the suction with gentleness, swiftness, and smooth movement.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	If there is any thickness in the blood, then he should be scarified twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	Now the first scarification opens a way for the subtilization of blood and its thinness; and the second is for the exquisite extraction of thick blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	But if the blood is very foul, then a third scarification ought to be made, in order to obtain the ultimate purpose.Et in omni scarificatione praecipitur, ut superius ad inferiorem partem: et ab interioribus ad exteriora.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And in every scarification it is directed to go from the upper to the lower part, and from within outwards. And at last when we desire to extract blood a little or but slightly, one scarification suffices us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	But if we desire the extraction of much blood, then we scarify with many scarifications more. Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure that the blood is thick, then it behooves us to scarify with a deep scarification; and an equal limit in scarification is the depth of the skin.Et si nos uolumus scarificari pro magnifice: tunc oportet, ut scarificemus plures scarificationes ad locum unum: et quolibet scarificamus scarificationem profundam.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What it is that must be administered from oils when placing wind-instruments, and what to beware of when using them.
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	In such a case as this, where the skin is coarse, tough, dusky, and the pores are tight, it is necessary to anoint the parts with wind-instruments with oils that are opening, soothing, relaxing: if it is in summer time, such as Alkeiri oil, or oil of violets, or oil of sweet almonds, or oil of cucumber seed.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in winter time, then Narcissus oil, or oil of lily, or chamomile oil, or savoy oil: and such like.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	If however the superfluity is coarse, cold: then let the oil be of amaracin, or of balsamita, or white oil, or aniseed oil: and such like.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	If however the wind-instrument is of large pores, thin skin: then it is necessary that this should be prohibited from oil, and it is necessary for these to wash the parts of their wind-instruments after wind-singing with rosewater, or with cold water, or with water of solatory, or of cucumber seed, or of purslane: and such like.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	But he whose blood is of much moisture, washes the wind-instruments with vinegar, or with water of myrrh, and sumach: and such like.Illi qui est sanguinis securii et tenui, et pori eius sunt patentes, oportet ut ungantur cum oleis calidiis, et secandis: si est in hyemali tempo, sicut est oleum balsamitis, aut uini rubei, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amygdalis amarorum.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	Whose also are gross, wash his wounds with old wine, or with water of salt-sarcocolla, or with a decoction of fennel, or chamomile: and such like.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	And it is necessary that the bleeding should be stopped in the bath or in the dressing-room of the bath; nay, it is necessary that it should be administered after leaving the bath by an hour, or two.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	And no one ought to sleep after bleeding.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	§ What is it that ought to be done by a Wind-drawer or a Blood-letter before bleeding?
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	AND after it is necessary that you consider in the first place; then if the Wind-drawn or Blood-let man be choleric, and prevail over his blood acuteness and inflammation, then it is necessary that he should take cooling things, as pomegranate grape; and also endive with vinegar and lettuce, and poppy seeds, and aniseed: and such like.Et etiam si post sanguinis missam sentiat ventris dolorem, oportet eum ut accipiat sucum raddis apii, aut malva cum mella, aut sucum siligii cum mella, aut sucum lininum, aut silphium cum mella: aut etiam uentam de mella et oleo et aqua calida: et eis similibus.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	And give him the young of his food, and mutton meat cooked in a pot, and savoury food with herbs; and like things.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	And when his constitution is cold, he should drink syrups of honey, or of almice, or of sweet alsecabins made from nuts; and he should drink moderately of perfumed wine which is between old and new; and it is best that he should use small quantities of food.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	And give him the young of his food, and meat cooked in a pot; and larks, that is small birds, and the young of pigeons roasted.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	And it is necessary that the drink on the day of cupping and blood-letting should be more than the food; and it is best to give in the drink to some men in the hours of tyring alfaroch, or medicine from moss, that is, muscade, or alselithe before cupping; and before blood-letting, or after: so that the principal members are strengthened, and the blood refined.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	And they should not drink it in heated drink.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	Of cups without scarification.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	But those cups which are without scarification, are cups which are put on the liver, and spleen, and podagra, and on the belly, navel, and places of the kidneys, and anus; because these members will not suffer scarification upon them.Et ponuntur super loca uulnera, et ulceras, et eritematosa, et prurigos, et lues: et super omnia loca quae non potest ponere medicamentum: nam in his ventosis quaecunque ponuntur, percutiantur cum spathula.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	And they are not questioned about them except either a flow of blood from one limb to another: as when we put Ventosa on the breasts in a nosebleed.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	And we use them, to dissolve cold moisture from one limb into another: as when we put ventosa on the belly, and navel.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	For it rarefies the limb, and warms it, and removes the pain because of that, as it dissolves that moisture.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	It is also put on the kidneys, when there is a stone or ulcer.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	Because of its attractive power perhaps it opens up the constriction, or erases the stone from its place.Quod si in uentrim ponatur, ut soluatur ventrem et menses, non debet ponere Ventosam super omnia membra.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	And likewise it does when placed on the liver and spleen at a cold moisture in either of them.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	And these ventosas are applied hollow with an incision only.Ita quoque facit Ventosa, quando ponitur super omnia membra, ubi debet fieri solutionis per omnia membra, ut soluatur uentositatem frigidam.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	And likewise the ventosa does when placed on all limbs, where there is to be made a solution through all limbs, as it dissolves cold moisture.And sometimes they are applied with fire.Et omnia Ventosae sint uacuae, nisi debet ponere ventriculus cum sectione, sed non debet ponere ventrem cum sectione, nisi per uentriculum.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	And sometimes hot water is administered to patients with pleurisy; and that is, in order to fill the wound-cup, there being used either hot water alone or water in which herbs suitable for the purpose have been boiled.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	Here follows the manner of administering fire-cupping.
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.	Let the size of its aperture be that of two fingertips opened wide, according to what we have described; and let its depth be half a palm; and let there be in its side, in a place which is about its middle, a small hole, according to the quantity which enters it, with the needle: let it be made out of brass or citron-wood, having thick edges, smooth, equal and polished, so that it may not injure the limb upon which it lies; and let there be in its middle a transverse rod of brass or iron, whereon is placed the candle with the fire.
Et iam fit haec uentosa magna, maior ea quam narrauimus, et parum minor illa, secundum aegritudines et aetatem eius qui utitur.	And now this great cupping-glass is made, larger than that which we have described, and somewhat smaller according to the illnesses and age of him who uses it.
Ventosae enim puerorum, et extenuatorum sunt aliae, quam uentosae uirorum, et grossorum corporum.	For the cupping-glasses of boys are different from those of grown men and corpulent persons.
Qualitas autem ponendi hanc uentosam cum igne super membrum, est, ut accendas licinium cum igne ex lino decenter, aut candelam paruam ex caera: et pone eam super medium uirgae transuersae quae est in medio uentosae: ut sit accensus ignis circiter inferiorem partem uentosae, ut non comburatur corpus infirmi.	But the manner of placing this cupping-glass with fire upon a limb is, that you should ignite some flaxen thread decently with fire, or a small candle out of wax; and place it upon the middle of the transverse rod which is in the midst of the cupping-glass, so that the fire burns around its lower part, lest the body of the patient be burnt.
Deinde ponatur super membrum: et digitus sit super foramen quod dixi, donec quando tenemus uentosam: dum indigemus, auferamus digitum, et egredietur uapor super illud foramen, et soluetur uentosa statim.	Then let it be placed upon the limb; and let a finger be upon the hole which I said, until we hold the cupping-glass: while we need, let us remove the finger, and the vapour will go forth through that hole, and the cupping-glass will come off at once.
Deinde igni licinium secundum modum suum, et itera eam, si indiges illa.	Then ignite the flaxen thread according to its need, and repeat it if you are in need of it.Ita fit haec uentosa administrata cum igne: ut per ignem expiatur superficies corporis.
In Ventosa autem quae administratur in aegritudine pleuresis cum aqua, non est uirga transuersa, neque foramen: et non administratur, nisi quia impletur aqua, et ponitur super membrum tantum.	This is the manner of administering the cupping-glass with fire, in order that by means of the fire the surface of the body may be purged.But the cupping-glass which is administered in pleurisy with water has no transverse rod or opening; and it is not administered except because it is filled with water and merely placed upon the limb.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et haec Ventosa quanto plus est magna, ut capiat aquam multam, est melior.	And this bellows, the larger it is so that it can hold much water, the better it is.
¶ De suspensione Sanguisugarum.	Of the suspension of bloodletting.
Caput XCIX.	Chapter 99.Et haec est forma eius.
Sanguisugae non administrantur in pluribus, nisi in quibus membris non est possibilis positio uentosarum, propter paruitatem eorum, sicut labium, et gingiua, et eis similia.	Leeches shall not be applied to many parts, unless where the position of cupping-glasses is not possible on account of their small size, as in the lip, the gums, and similar places.Caput C.
Aut in membro denudato a carne, sicut digitus, et nasus, et eis similia.	Or upon a member stripped of flesh, as the finger, the nose, and similar places.Caput CI.De sanguisugis in membris denudatis usitatis forma.
Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.	And the quality of using them is: that you take leeches from sweet waters, clean from putrefactions.
Deinde dimittantur die et nocte in aqua dulci, donec famelicae sint, et non remaneat in uentre earum aliquid.	Then they are left in the sweet water for a day and night until they are hungry, and nothing remains in their stomachs.
Deinde euacuetur corpus in primis cum phlebotomia, et cum uentosis.	Then the body is evacuated first with bloodletting and with enemas.
Deinde absterge membrum infirmi, donec rubeat.	Then wash the sick person's limb until it turns red.
Postea ponantur super ipsum.	Afterwards they are placed upon him.
Cum ergo implentur, et cadunt, et est possibilis suctio loci cum uentosa, tunc est magis ultimum in iuuamento: et si non, tunc ablue locum cum aceto.	When they are full and have fallen off, and there is possible a sucking of the site with an enema, then it is best to finish with the enema; if not, wash the site with vinegar.Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.
Deinde cum aqua multa, et fricetur, et exprimatur.	And the quality of using them is: that you take leeches from sweet waters, clean from putrefactions; then with much water and it is rubbed and pressed out.
Quod si prolongatur cursus sanguinis post casum Sanguisugarum, et est illud resudando: tunc infunde pannum lini in aqua frigida, et pone ipsum desuper, donec abscindatur resudatio.	If the flow of blood continues after the falling off of the leeches and it is oozing out then pour a linen cloth into cold water and place it over it, until the oozing ceases;
Quod si multiplicatur sanguis, tunc pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, aut gallas, et similia eis ex stipticis: donec abscindatur sanguis.	If the blood is profuse then powder over it powdered zaygo, or gall-nuts, and similar things made from astringents until the blood ceases;
Aut ponantur super locum medietates fabarum excorticatarum: et dimittantur, donec adhaereant fabae in loco, nam sanguis abscinditur.	Or place over the site half-peelings of beans that have been shelled and let them remain until they adhere to the site; for the blood will be stopped.Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.
Et oportet si necessaria est iteratio Sanguisugarum, quando est possibile, mutare eas.	And the quality of using them is: that you take leeches from sweet waters, clean from putrefactions; and when it is necessary to repeat the bloodletting with leeches, they should be changed when possible.Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.
Si autem prohibentur Sanguisugae a suspensione, tunc abstergatur locus cum sanguine recenti.	If on the other hand the leeches are prevented by clotting, then wash the site with fresh blood;
Aut fige acum in locis, donec egrediatur aliquid ex sanguine.	Or pierce the spots with an acupunture needle until something flows out from the blood;
Deinde ponantur, nam ipsae quando sentiunt aliquid ex sanguine, adhaerent statim.	Then place them on the site; for as soon as they sense something of the blood, they will immediately adhere.Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.
Quando ergo uis ut cadant, pulueriza super eas aliquid ex aloe trito, aut salem, aut cinerem: et cadent statim.	When you therefore wish them to fall down, sprinkle over them some powdered aloe or salt or ashes, and they will at once fall down.
¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	The End of the Second Part
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	Albucasis's Surgical Book Third Part
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	A General Discourse on Restoration and Dislocation and the Treatment of Wounds and Similar Things.
Caput I.	Chapter 1.
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	This Chapter is also often necessary in the art of Medicine, and it is the restoration of fractures and dislocations of accidents in bones. It treats of their cause, symptoms, cure, and prognostications.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.	Know you, O Sons, that the foolish physicians and the common people boast of this Chapter, and have not examined an ancient book nor read a letter out of it. Yet they say that they cure all dislocations with one or two remedies: but if they see a dislocation in a bone, they are unable to determine its cause.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	And because of this, this method has been deprived of knowledge in our land.
