They apply hot poultices and bandages around the dislocated part: but they do not know what causes dislocation. Now I will explain briefly about these things, that you may understand them clearly in your minds, O Students of Medicine.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	And I have not attained to any good at all therein, nor have I attained that which I have attained save because of the length of reading the ancient books and studying them until I extracted their knowledge from them. But this Chapter is called by some The General Discourse, and by others The Universal Discourse, on account of its treating briefly and generally of dislocations, and of the cause thereof, and of the symptoms and the treatment thereof; for in it is contained a summary of all the dislocations of the body:
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	Then I adhered to experiment and study throughout my life. The first kind of dislocation is that which takes place through violence, as when one part of the body comes into violent contact with another, and this is in most cases accompanied by a loud noise, as when one falls and dislocates his hip or shoulder: now this is called Contusion, and it is in all cases to be expected that there will follow from such a dislocation swelling, lividity, pain, and inability to move the limb.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	And now I have described to you in this Chapter all that my science contains; and beyond what my experiment has passed over, after I have shortened it for you, and liberated it from the occupation of elongation, and shortened it at its end of shortening, and shown it at the end of its declination: and formed in it many forms out of the forms of instruments which are administered in it, when it is from the addition of declination, as I made in two preceding Chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	Summae and collections from the existence of fractures of the bones, from those whose previous emission is necessary, before we begin the reminder of the members of fractures, and different ones of each one.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	It is appropriate, as we say in the prologue to this chapter, that summaries of the discourse and chapters from which its understanding is required first of all by the artist at their truth: namely, so that you may know, or learn this noble art, and others from you.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	I say, therefore, that when it happens to someone a fracture, or dislocation, or torque, or case: then you must hurry first of all to let the blood and dissolve him, or both at the same time, if something does not prohibit anything, such as weakness of strength, or he is one of those who had something from them, or a decrepit old man, or the time of intense heat, or intense cold.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	Then let him be restrained in his food, cold vegetables, and meat of rams and goats, and forbid wine, and coarse meats, and full from foods and all foods that fill the veins with blood.Et si non possit abstinere a carnibus grossis: tamen omnes eorum carnes sint paruo coctae, et saepe potus.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	Until you are secure from the hot pustule and do not fear the effusion of matter to the limb; then let the invalid return to his first diet with which he has become accustomed.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	When therefore the broken bone begins to be restored, then it is necessary that the invalid be fed with nourishing foods, much, coarse, heavy food, in which there is moisture: as meals made from cooked wheat with water, and peas, and heads, and feet, and bellies of beans, and eggs, and fresh fish: and thick wine, and similar to these.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	For by this diet the coagulation of the broken place is made more quickly and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	And you should know that bones which are broken when they are in old men and decrepit men, it is not possible for them to be continued and consolidated according to their nature always, because of the drying up of their limbs; and they are consolidated and continued those who are in them at the end of softness, as bones of children.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	Nevertheless nature connects on the broken bone from every part something similar to glue, in which there is thickness, with which it adheres and tightens it until they are glued together, and bound together, until it comes to an end of strength and firmness, as it was at first, until it does not prohibit it from anything in its operations; and because of this reason, it is necessary to put the food of the invalid in foods in which there are heaviness, and moisture, and thickness, as we said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	And you should know that the species of fractures are diverse, according to the diversity of the limbs; for a fracture of the leg is different from a fracture of the bone of the head: and a fracture of the bone of the chest is different from a fracture of the bone of the back; and likewise all other limbs are all diverse from one another; and I come with remembrance of all the species of fractures exposed in its own chapter, distinct from another.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	And the species of fractures of bones are also different in themselves.Quod enim est fractura in parte superius ossis, siue superius uel infimus, est diuersum a fractura in parte medio.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	Because this fracture is bowed, apart from what happens to it, stars are incident upon it.
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	And sometimes the fracture is along the length of the bone; and its fractures are serrated, that is, stars, and additions proceeding just as they are in a reed when a pen is applied to write with it.
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	And they do not proceed; and the fracture is accompanied by a wound and disruption of the head: and there is a small fracture with fissure.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	And every species has its own nature or tool in the restoration of it, according to what will come as a reminder of it, distinguished in its places.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	And from that by which the fracture of bone is known, is its crookedness, and its own eminence; and its appearance to the sense, and its sound when you press it with your hand.
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	When therefore there is no crookedness apparent in the place, nor any sound at your touch as you feel the bone with vibration, nor does the invalid find much pain; then there is no fracture there at all, but rather it is possible that it is a crookedness or small fissure: it is not right therefore to move it at all with your hand and compression, but rather place over it from remedies of which comes reminder, after that momentum which it convenes in its place: then it must be bound with a subtle bandage.
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And know, that when the place bows and is split in two, apart from what happens in it of serrations, however all part is removed from its fellow: then you must begin from your hour to the rectification of it, by making it even before any hot ulcer happens to it.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	But if a hot ulcer happens to it, then leave it for some days, until the apostema quiets down.Et post ea dies, quando uisum est tibi, ut incipias ad rettificationem, ponas super ipsum olea masticata et resineratam, cum cotisati subtegmen, et facias super eum ad modium ligaturam.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	And after a few days when you see fit to begin rectification, put over it masticated oil and resin with a thin covering, and make a moderately tight bandage over it.Then even it out according to whatever way it can from its softness and nature.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	And know that the restoration and leveling of it is easier than bone, where cracks occur.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	Then tighten it, according to how it will come to you the memory of it.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	If, however, there are cracks in the bone, then extension of this fractured limb is necessary from two parts, if it is a hand or foot: or with your hand, if it is a small member: or with two cords, or with a cord and a hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	And let your position be as you place the member above an equal place, according to its natural figure, until when the parts of the fractured limb are extended: then try, with all your skill, to make these additions in their places: and beware according to your strength, lest pain or injury occur through your operation; and try according to your strength, to apply one of two bones with its partner, according to better forms.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	And it behooves you at that time, to tent and touch it with your hand.Et si non possis, quod est optimi operis, fac etiam, quod potes: sed non debes remittere, donec quaeris, quem modum possis facere melius.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	If therefore you see there something different, rectify it and make it equal by the quantity of your strength.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	And beware extreme extension and strong compression, as many stupid people do.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	Often indeed they cause to come about through their operation a hot ulcer, or a contraction in the limb; as we have already seen that often from their operations.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	Then attach after the equalization, and decent operation, and tightening of that limb, and rest, and tranquility: and admonish the infirm one over him.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	And let him keep quiet, so that he does not move it during the hours of his vigils, and sleep at his turn, and his agitation, and in his need, and all his movements with his last strength.Et faciatur super eum memento per signum apud ipsum.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	And so that it can be prevented, that there is a position of the member with which pain ensues.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	This is because when it feels in the disposition of a member's position either pain or injury, then it is necessary that he change it to another disposition from that with which he doesn't feel pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	And take care with him so that its position is equal and straight, so that there isn't crookedness of the member when it's restored.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the binding of a broken member is, according to what I narrate.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	Know that members differ in their smallness and magnitude and their shape.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	Those then which are small like an arm, and a finger, and a toe, and similar to these, then it is necessary that there be a winding of a soft, thin cloth.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	But those which are thick like a thigh and leg, it is necessary that there be a wide, hard winding in them.Et si membrum sit in medio inter utramque partes, sicut est brachium aut crus, quod ad alterum alterum pertinet, et non ad modicum amplius alicuius parte, sed pariter:
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	For the ligament connects a large member and binds it from every part by an equal binding so that no spot enters it.Et si latus sit in qualibet parte membrorum magnarum, sicut coxis et crucis, et alterius ad alteram pertinet, quod est ad modicum amplius alicuius parte, non pariter:
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	Then after your evacuation from equality begin to place a convenient plaster on it, on the soft sponge over the fracture site.Positaque stuppa, positoque linimento: incipias membrum, sub eo quod est sub ea, ut supra dictum est, ad modum ad modum mutare.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	Then begin to wrap the ligament over the fracture site with three windings or four, according to how much the member deserves, and hold your hand firm with the ligament.Et sic iterum, ad modum ad modum, usque ad finem quod tu nequas pluris ad stringendas ligaturas per inuoluturas.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	Then go with it to the top part from the fracture site and bind less than your binding was which bound the broken place.Positaque inuolutione, ut supra dictum est: incipias mutare membrum per partes, ut dictum est.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	Then lengthen it with a little rotation from the site of the fracture, and gradually relax the constriction until you grasp a large portion of sound tissue from that site.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	Then take another thread and wind it again over the fractured site.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	Then apply the rotation to the lower part near the fracture.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	And your operation on the constriction of the rotation and its relaxation must be according to what we have said concerning the first upper rotation.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	Then place between the rotations a little cotton or cloth, which will equalize the twist of the fracture, if there is any twist; but if there is none, then do not put anything in it.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	Then wind another thread over it.Et si non potes tollere rem magnam ex loco sano, neque per inuolutionem, nec per uiuificationem, sed eam sentis flexibiliter adplexatam circa fracturam:
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	And if you cannot take off a large portion of sound tissue from that site, neither by rotation nor relaxation, but you feel it flexibly bent about the fracture:Then over these rotations immediately and evenly put splints skillfully made, provided there is no inflammation or hot abscess at the site.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	If however there is an inflammation or an abscess in it; then put over that what sits on the abscess and remove the inflammation; and leave it for a few days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	Then tighten the splints over it.Et post aliquot dies, si non est inflatio, aut apostema: et si fractura est uia flexione, in quo sentis inflexionem flexibilem, et si non potes tollere rem magnam ex loco sano: tunc equa utramque parte super astellas inuolue filis.
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	And let there be stars made of the middle parts of a cane split, shaved and formed wisely; or let them be made out of wood such as is used for colanders, which are made from pinewood, or of gerah, that is, branches of palm trees, or of calamus: and let all the size of the stars follow this shape, and this same figure.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	However, it is necessary that the star which is placed above the same bar be thicker and wider by a small amount than the other stars; and let the length of the stars follow according to what can be permitted by the magnitude and smallness of the member.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	Then draw with a thread another string over the stars according to the first bar the same.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	Then tie with threads decently over this according to what we have said about the bar; and it is necessary that your bar be over the place of the fracture more, and as far as the fracture extends, let the bar be less.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	And it is necessary that the threads be medium in thickness and fineness, and that they be made of soft flax.Quod si facias, hec omnia curat, ut sint sanitatem praestantia, vel quasi mox postea: et si non possit cadere, profectum est bonum, et debet durare diu, cum illo qui urit in se ad somnum, donec curari poterit.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	For if you do so, all these things cure, that they are excellence of health, or almost immediately afterwards; and if it cannot fall, it is good, and it must last a long time, with him who burns in himself to sleep, until it can be cured.For if the threads are thick, as I have seen from the operation of foolish people putting their threads from twisted linen cords, there is a great error; because the bar falls with them outside quality.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	And thin threads also do not suit: for you do not pursue through the bar with them that which you wish.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	And it is not necessary that there be between star and star less than a finger.Quod si facis, tu non conueneris per eam quae ponitur super locum fracturae: nam illa debet esse in medio inter astellas.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	If a weak person is hurt by the ends of the splints after tightening them in healthy places, then place beneath them a gentle sponge or dyed wool until nothing is hurt from this.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	But when there is a fracture with a wound, and disruption occurs in the skin, I will come with remembrance of this in chapter two according to its uniqueness.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	And you shall know that not every fractured limb ought to be tightened with splints from the first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	This is because when the limb is large, you ought not to place splints on it unless after five, or seven, or more days, according to your confidence regarding the outcome of the hot blister.Quod si est in membra parvo, post diem tertium aut quartum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis, nisi accidit vulneri quod non potest curari, sed debet esse per se uelut fractura quae curatur cum iudicio.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	And this is the way of the plaster casts that the ancients used to restore, which are placed over the fracture and dislocation.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	¶ Way of the common short plaster cast, restoring fracture, suitable for most complexions, especially women and children: because it has no effect on heat or cold.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	And it is that you take from the powder of the mill, and there is a core of flour which hangs on the walls of the mill at the movement of the millstone; and you prepare it as it is, except that you sift it with white chalk: and put the mixture not thick, nor subtle.Et ponas super ipsum olebrosum, ut placet tibi, et facias illum plenum, ne cadat ex eo puluere intra, quia per se sufficit.
Deinde utere eo.	Then use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	Here is another method of a plaster that heals fractures, dislocations and twists:
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	Take equal parts of alum, sal-ammoniac, acacia gum, enula and mithridate; and ten parts each of myrrh and aloe, twenty parts of altheyl, grind them all, strain and mix with alethyl water: or with egg white if the patient's complexions is warm.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	Then use this plaster.
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	This is indeed a good composition, quickly restoring broken bones and helping many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	Here is another method for a plaster that also helps fractures and twists:
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	Take equal parts of mithridate, mess, and white altheyl, ten parts each of myrrh and aloe, six parts acacia, and twenty parts Armenian bole; grind them all with much trituration, strain and make into a plaster with water or egg: and apply it.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	Here is a method for a plaster that joins joints, and bones separated from their sockets; and it eases the pain of those affected by wound, bone fracture, and dislocation:
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	Take wool with sweat, and soak it in hot vinegar and oil: and place it on the affected area.
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	And this plaster indeed has no healing power; but it is good for easing a hot abscess and removing pains indeed.¶ Modus Emplastri ad scissuras ossium.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	Here is a method for a plaster that heals bone fractures:
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	Take the leaves of the fig tree and the leaves of wild poplar; grind them all together and make a plaster from both.Et placet mox super os fractum, et tenetur cum ligatura: et datur infusio amborum ad potum.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	The method of the abbreviated plaster, applied at the restoration of a fractured bone; and when you wish to bring about the resolution of a residual abscess.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	Take equal parts of the root of the alder tree, and camomile, and the flowers of the elder, and flour of nettle; crush them all together and make it into a paste with wine, unless the limb is hot.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	If however it is hot, then prepare it with wet coriander water, or water and use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	Another method of a stronger plaster for resolution, than the first one, when there is a hard abscess at the restoration of a limb:
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	Take equal parts of the root of the alder tree, and linseed, and myrrh, and honey-lute, and marshmallow, and the flowers of the elder, and camomile; crush them all together and make it into a paste with willow water, or sweet water, or wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	Apply this according to the warmth of the limb, and the quietness of its heat.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	Hippocrates however did not say in his book, that this should be laid on a fractured limb at its restoration, unless made into a poultice from lard and honey; nothing else; and he described it as being a medium between coarseness and thinness.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	Galen however saw fit that things be laid on a fractured limb at its restoration, which have a drying heat such as myrrh and aloe and frankincense, and things similar to these of which we spoke.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	The method of a plaster which acts on a wound and pain:
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	Take mugwort, and peas, and human hair snipped, or bird feathers, and alder, and salt in equal parts; crush them all together, sift them, and make a plaster of it.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	However the quantity should be according to what is appropriate so that it remains in place as a ligature, and then dissolves; then you must consider when this does not cause pain, or itching, or move the broken bone out of its place: then do not dissolve it on many days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	If a violent itching or uneasy pain, or swelling, should attack it, then quickly remove the plaster from off it, and wash the spot with warm water, until the itching is appeased, and the pain is still'd.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	Then leave the limb to rest for an hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	Then place over the spot a piece of wool soaked in vinegar and oil, or rose-oil; and bind it there for the night, until you are sure that the hot wound is healed up, and the swelling of the limb is laid, and its pain removed.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the same slight compression and slight plaster until it is healed up. And do not at first bind it too tight, or too long with you, until it is cured.Si autem accidat apostema in locis interioribus: sicut in inguine, vel axillae, vel in mammis mulierum: et non possis ad eum per verum manum, neque per aliam personam: tunc propera et trahe unguium suum, et fac ut sanguis fluat: et itera postea emplastrum, sicut antea dictum est.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	But if an ulcer should happen in the inward parts, as in the groin, or armpit, or in women's breasts; and you cannot come at it with your hand, or any other person: then quickly cut its nail, and make the blood to flow; and repeat the plaster afterwards, as before said. But if you see that the ulcer is quite gone, and the redness, and the swelling, and all the accidents thereof are quite removed, and you have need of plaster and compression, then repeat it as you did at first in equal manner.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	But if nothing of what we have said hath happened to the limb, then don't loosen it unless after three days, or four, or five, or seven.Et si tunc quiescat, et non sit inflatio, neque rubedo, neque dolor, sed stat immobile: et sanguis non fluat ex apostemato, aut de venis circa ipsum: tunc scire debes, quod non curabitur, nisi per medicamentum internum.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	And when that is let twenty days, all of it, according as it appears to you from the solution of the member, as we have said, until the fracture adheres and the coagulation of the flesh approaches over it: add then also in stricture more than your first whole stricture: and add also in the engrossing of the food of the infirmary, according to what has preceded the memory of it.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	But if you see the place of the fracture to dry out and become wasted more than it should, then know that food is prohibited from reaching it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	Moisten therefore the place with warm water at every bathing and let it be so for all three days, and ease the stricture a little.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	By this operation food is thus sent to the member, and it is healed quickly.Post remissionem autem septimanas tres, vel quodlibet peruersum facies, si non possit ambulare, sed sit in curriculo: et mande illum ambulare ad omnem uicem qua soluis, et per omnia loca qua soluis, et per omnes uices qua soluis.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	But after the remission of three weeks or whatever perversion you do, if it cannot walk but sit in a curricle: and command him to walk at every bath where he bathes, and through all places where he bathes, and through all baths where he bathes.That then which they, the foolish restaurateurs, do on account of a fractured member another manner, when it is not restored in the first place as it ought, but is restored according to tortuosity, is error out of their operation, and a great fear: and if it were straight, the ancients would have said so in their books, and operated with it.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	And I did not see anywhere of them any vestige in that at all, and it is better that that not be done.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	Of the making of an accident on the head.Si autem uisit te accidente in capite quolibet omnino genere, et non possit peruinire ad locum accidentis, sed sit ibi adhaerens sicut uultus, utpote carnis uinculum, et si postea non possit ambulare: cum debet peruinire illuc ad omnem uicem qua soluis, et non possit peruinire illuc, sed debet sedere in curriculo, et mande illum ambulare ad locum accidentis ad omnem uicem qua soluis.
Caput III.	Chapter III.De factura accidente in capite per contusionem, cum sanguine et sine sanguine.
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	The species of fracture are diverse, and its figures many; and its causes are distinct.Uniusque eius modum habemus ut faciamus per contusionem ad caput cum sanguine et sine sanguine, et per dehiscensiam: et facimus eam in locis quolibet quasi quolibet omnino genere, et qua libet persona.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	There is a fracture from a blow with an axe; and the blow destroys the whole bone as it penetrates to the pith, which is inside the bone, just as an axe does to wood; and for this reason this kind of fracture is called axial.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	Or an axe hits something in the bone and hits its surface but the cut does not penetrate to the very end of it; and this kind of fracture is called Kalaan, that is, an absolute slit.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	And there is a wound of two fractures, either great or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	And from fracture is that which is a contusion, or an attrition; and its cause is a blow with a stone, or falling on a stone, or similar things.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	And this fracture is also either penetrating, which comes close to the membrane, which is under the bone, or it is in the surface of the bone; and a wound of these two fractures is also either small or great.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	And from fracture is that which is hidden in the bone, like a hair; and it is a small crack, and for this reason this kind of fracture is called Capillaris.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	And from these is a fracture that occurs from a fall or a blow of a stone and similar things, which cause the sheet of bone to enter inwards, and it becomes hollow inside: just as happens to bronze kettles when they are hit, and a part of them enters inwards.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	And indeed most often it occurs in the heads of moist bones, such as the heads of children.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	And all these kinds of fractures are separated from one another; and I will come back with a reminder of them all in their place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	And we know all these kinds of fractures by detection on them and by examination with tests and by removal of the rotten flesh that is above them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	The kind called Capillaris, however, is known by this, that it is uncovered on the bone and wiped off, and liniment is applied over it; for the fracture appears black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	In treating a fracture, consider first the patient's condition; then if you see from the symptoms that there is clear danger beyond fear, such as vomiting of blood and bile, loss of intellect, loss of speech, fainting, acute fever, protrusion and redness of the eyes, and similar symptoms in many parts, without doubt it will not be cured. And if you see no terrifying symptoms and hope for a cure: then begin its treatment.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	If a wounded person comes to you immediately after being wounded: and it is in the winter days, then you should remove the bone before the fourteenth day according to every indication.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	And if it is in the summer days, then you should hasten to remove the bone before the seventh day, before what is under the bone is corrupted from the skin, and those symptoms we have described occur.Et si est in diebus octobris vel novembris, et non possis remouere os ante diem tertiam decimus, postea non remoue, ne resorbeatur ossa, et corrumpe omnia quae sub eo sunt.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	If the fracture of the bone has already reached the membrane touching the brain and is accompanied by minute particles and traction, then you must cut away the comminuted and crushed part as I have described to you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	You should then examine the head of the wounded man and expose the bone as best you can according to the nature of the wound and in accordance with its shape and position over the injury.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	If when you are exposing the bone a flow of blood or a hot blister occurs, then apply to it what is appropriate for it.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	And you should fill the wound with winesoaked bandages and rose oil, and let the wound rest until the blister has settled, and be confident that there will be no flow of blood.Quod si apud comminutionem ossis, aut uulnus in quolibet loco corporis, accidat tibi fluxus sanguinis: tunc oportet, ut facias ligaturam cum panno, et trahas eum ad modum bracchii super os fractum.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	If a flow of blood occurs with the comminution of the bone or any wound in any part of the body, then you must make a ligature with a bandage and draw it like an armband over the broken bone.Then begin the cure of the bone and its removal.Et est, ut fodias uulnus cum scalpele ad modum crucis: et trahas de medio ossem comminutum, et attritum.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	And it is done according to one of two methods.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	Indeed, one method is to cut the bone with a sharp-edged knife; and this is its form.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	Then insert the knife again a little further apart from the first incision, making it a little wider each time: and this is its form.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	Then also insert another incision even wider still than the second.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	And the second method is that you have a number of knives with different widths; some are broader than others and some narrower. They should be very sharp at their ends and made of steel or iron. You will find it easier to strike them on top of the incision so that they do not jar and harm the head.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	But if the bone is very hard, then you must pierce it all around before using the knives, with boring tools called trepans which do not go through to the other side of the bone beyond its fleshy surface. This is because they have a round tip at their lower end like an edge and a small circle prevents them from penetrating deeply into the bone.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	You should have a large number of these trepans so that each one suits the thickness of bone until you can press on every part of the skull with the trepan. The amount by which its sharp end exceeds in length and is shorter, according to the thickness of that part of the skull.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	And this is the shape of the three types of saws [or] trepans.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	The quality of the boring through the rim of the broken bone is as follows: you place the trepan over the bone and rotate it with your fingers until you know that the bone has already been penetrated.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	Then change the trepan to another location and place between every hole a quantity equal to the thickness of a radius or about that.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	Then cut with an incision what is between each hole from the bone: and make it thinner than you can on its end out of thinness, as we said, until you scrape off the bone, or by your hand, or with some other of the tools which you prepared for it, such as tweezers, and fine forceps.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	And it is necessary that you beware with every precaution that the trepan or the incision does not touch anything of the brain.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	When therefore you go around the bone boring and it has been separated from the brain, if it is continuous with it, and you have pulled it out, you must scrape and smooth its end which remains in the bone with another similar instrument, an incision tool.Et si fuerit fractum os intra siphac, oportet ut trahas eam partem qua fracta est, donec omnia ossa quae intra sunt perfora, et eradicessit: sed nequaquam perferas per ossa quae extra sunt siphac.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	However, it must be thin and subtle rather than thick compared with other knives.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	If anything remains of the small bones and fragments, then take them out with ease using the instruments you have at hand.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	Then treat the wound after that with poultices and ointments as we have said.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	And there is another mode of operation that is easy, indeed remote from fear; which Galen spoke of and praised it with high praise; and this is his statement.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	It is necessary for you in the first place to begin by removing the bone from the spot where the fracture is more serious and manifest; until when you have removed that part, and placed underneath it the extremity of this crescent knife, of which this is the shape.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	And the rounded part does not cut anything; and the acute part of it, spreading on both sides of it in length, as you see; so that the rounded part rests against the bone, with its acute face cutting into the bone.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	Then strike the knife with a small hammer from one side, until you cut through all the bone with ease, as it is rolled out; and you need have no fear whatsoever that an accident will happen to you because of this.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	And if the surgeon were not foolish and more ignorant of it, or were not sleepy, then if anything remained attached to the bone in some spots, he would cut it away from there with the extremity of his crescent knife, and free it from it with ease.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	For it is freed from it without harm and without fear.Quod si non esset liberatum, cum illo restaret aliquid ex panniculo: et quilibet medicus scit, ut sit in id necesse, ut liberetur totum: nam si non liberatur, ueniet ibi ex eo morbus ueteranus.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	And if the fracture of the bone does not penetrate to the membrane, and that which is cut away from the bone is its surface, and remain in it subtle roughnesses and fragments: then you ought to smooth over that roughness and uproot those fragments with fine scrapers from among which you have prepared a number of different quantities, so that it may be possible for you to apply from them in every spot what is most suitable and most correct of them, according to that to which the operation leads you, and the fractured bone itself, and its shape.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	And it is necessary that you apply them with your own hand, as we said before regarding the roots of teeth, more broadly than those razors.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	Then use one beneath it which is finer.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	And you should not stop doing this continually until you reach the thinnest and most delicate of them all.
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	With each small crack, however, and delicate fracture, it is necessary that you apply treatment according to what leads to its correction.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	And it is a thing which is not hidden from anyone who has any skill at all in this art and who has studied what we have written and shown about great fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	If however the membrane is exposed when you pull out the tooth then you should take a piece of linen according to the size of the wound and soak it in rose oil and place it over the opening of the wound.Et tene curam istius, donec facias cum aqua calida infundum super os, et fac, ut intraiat super eam.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	Then take another piece of linen folded twice or three times and soak it in wine and rose oil and place it over the first piece of linen so that it does not weigh down on the wound.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	Then apply a wide bandage over it and do not tie it tightly except according to the quantity that holds only the wound: and leave it with this treatment for one day or two days until you are secure from a hot abscess.Et post ea, fac ut teneat sub ligamento uulnus tantum.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	Then solve it and apply medicines afterwards to drive out the superfluous dryness, such as lily root, herb flour, incense powder, aristolochia and similar things; and you should make a powder from these medicines, which is sprinkled over the wound just like the dry ones.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	And generally apply to it every medicine that has the property of cleansing and not biting.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	And beware according to your ability, lest the wound be foul in your treatment; neither let there be any unctuousness or foulness in it.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	And do not let the pus at all accumulate in it; because when pus gathers on the brain membrane, it corrupts and rots it, and great wickedness happens to the weak afterwards; and now it has happened with a wound in the head, when it is cleansed from that, especially when its treatment is neglected, blackness on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	Therefore consider then, if the events which we said happen to the weak, know without doubt that it is very dangerous.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	And if the blackness does not happen except from the medicine which is put on it, and is in the power of that medicine to make that blackness: then you should take a part of honey, three parts of rose oil, and linseed with them.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	Then put it on the wound; afterwards treat it with curing remedies which suit it, until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	Of the restoration of the nose when it is broken.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	Know that only two parts of the nose break at a time, or one of them; because it has two bones: for its lower part is cartilage and does not break, nor does anything happen to it except attrition, and tortuousness, and simili.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	If one of the two parts is broken, then you should insert your little finger into the nostril, and pull that fracture equally with your index and thumb fingers, until the nose returns to its natural shape; and it shall be done artfully and with ease.Et si franguntur omnes partes Nasi cum simplici fractura, et non est illa perniciosum, sed potest sanare: intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, donec sentiat dolorem: postea trahe eum, et pone super illam partem Nasi, ubi est fractura.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	And beware, lest the patient's pain be made worse by your operation.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	If the fracture is in the upper part of the nose and the finger cannot reach it, then you must make a small hole with a drill at the end of the radius where there is a small thickness.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	If, however, the fracture is in two places, then make a similar one; and restore it on the first day of the fracture if possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	And if not, then after the seventh or tenth day when the hot abscess is quiet.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	Then insert into the end of the nose a piece of linen if the fracture is in one place; or insert two pieces if the fracture is in two places; and let there be in the piece of linen a thickness of such quantity as will fill up the hole of the nose.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	And some of the ancient restorers said that the pieces of linen should be infused with butter and changed every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	But this does not seem to me right; rather the piece of linen should be infused with egg white, mixed with flour from a mill.Et postea intromittantur licinia in extremitatem Nasi ad restauracionem fracturae.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	Then leave it untouched until the bone is consolidated and the cartilage hardened.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	And sometimes a goose feather is inserted into the nose in place of licinius, after a soft bandage has been wrapped around it; and this holds the fracture of the nose more firmly, and so that the invalid is not hindered from breathing.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	This thing is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	If you wish, do it; and if you wish, do not do it.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	If, while you are operating on the aposteme, the nose should become hot again, apply to it a plaster with cerate, or with cotton wool infused in rose-oil, or with a little arsnical ointment.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	But if there is no hot aposteme, then you should apply to it a plaster of sesame-flour and powdered stibium mixed with white lead.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	Then put over this a soft bandage, and bind the nose with nothing at all.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	But if the bones of the nose are broken with a slight fracture, or crushed, then you should split them and draw them out with appropriate instruments.Et postea fac res ut suprascribitur de Naso uelato.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	Then heal that wound and heal it with the meat, and strengthen it from convenient bandages or ointments.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	But if a wound happen between the nose, then you must heal it with lint and apply a tube of lead until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	Of restoration of the lower jaw when it is broken.
Caput V.	Chapter 5.
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	When the lower jaw is broken and there is no wound; examine then if the break is only outward and not broken in two and healed towards the interior; then its knowledge is easy.Et si per casum, aut per uirtutem, faciunt se iuncturas: et non potest ad modum consuetuum curari: curas eam cum placenta, et oleo, et ligno: vel cum emplastro: et facis eam ut debet.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	If the fracture is on the right side, the left index finger must be introduced into the mouth of the patient; likewise if it is a fracture of the left jaw, then introduce the right index finger: and push the swelling of the fracture with ease towards the exterior with one hand from the interior part of the bone, and with the other hand push it equally towards the interior side.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	If the fracture of the jaw is already separated into two parts, then you must administer extension from both sides according to their rightness until its equalization is possible.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	But if the teeth have already been shaken, or broken off, then bind those of which you hope that they will remain with a thread of gold, or silver, or silk.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	Then put on the broken jaw a bandage made of wool.Quod si non possit inveniri filum aurum, vel argentum: tunc utere lintei.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	But if gold or silver thread cannot be found then use linen.Then put on top of the jaw a double bandage, and put over the bandage a large and decently made splint: or an equal piece of sole leather, in the length of the jaw.Et postea fac ut dormiat patientem qui est sub astella.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	Then bind it up from above, according to how you are prepared for its binding, and according to how it is proper for its application, until it is destroyed. And tell the sick person to use stillness and quiet; and give him gentle drinks for his food.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	If you judge that something is already altered in some way by any means, then hurry and loosen it on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	Then straighten what was altered of it from that, and apply a plaster to it of flour of mill, with white lead or with sesame flour, after you have removed the poultice: and place over the plaster soft wool.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	While therefore that attached plaster remains on it, and the disposition of the bone is not altered, leave it, so that you may not loosen it, until it is healed; or tighten the fracture.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	For often this fracture is tightened in three weeks.Si autem post tres septimas non curat, solva ipsum: et stringe iterum, donec curet.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	If however after three weeks it does not heal, loosen it; and tighten again, until it is healed. If in the meantime a hot pustule occurs, then apply what we said many times to its sedation, until that pustule is removed.Quod si accidit apostema frigidum, tunc ponito super ipsum emplastrum de farina panis et oleo: et pone super emplastırum sorbentiam calendam.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	And if the fracture comes with a wound, consider it.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	If the wound is already separated from the bone, or from the flesh: then you are to act subtly in this, that you take away those pieces of flesh with it which come away with them in their extraction from the instruments.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	If on the other hand the opening of the wound is narrow, then dilate it with a bloodletting instrument according to your needs.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	Then when you have taken away that flesh and nothing of it remains, then enlarge the opening of the wound, if it is large; and if not, put over it one of the bandages which are appropriate for that, and let it heal, until it is cured.Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	And if the fracture comes with a wound, consider it.¶ Of the restoration of the Fork-bone when it is broken.
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.De restoratione furculae cum uulnere quando frangitur: et de uulnere inter kostas cum fractura furculae.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	The furcula is indeed very frequently broken from the front part of the shoulder-blade, and the fracture of it happens in three ways.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	Or else it is broken and separated into two, without which the dislocation does not occur; and its restoration is more easy.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	Or again, that which occurs in the bone of the dislocation; and its restoration is more difficult.Atque haec trium modorum fractura fit per contusionem humeralis ossis.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	And this threefold fracture happens through a blow on the bone of the shoulder.Or again, that which is a fracture with a wound.Et in his tribus modis facies anterior humeri inflectitur ad interiorem partem et apud axillam.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	And in these three ways the front of the shoulder is bent towards the inner part and by the armpit. And the operation on it when the fracture is without a wound, is that you should have two assistants present, one of whom holds that which follows the broken furcula, and the other extends the neck towards the side.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	Then smooth the fracture with your fingers, until its shape is as it should be; and there must be no protuberance or depression on it.Et teneas eam ad mediam partem, donec confrimetur, secundum quod oportet: et non te movere a loco usque eo tempus.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	And hold it in the middle until it is set as it should be; and do not move from its place until that time.If you need more extension, then you must put under the patient's armpit a ball of cloth or wool, the size of which is according to the amount of your necessity; and extend and raise the furcula, and contract the ball with your hand, until the fracture is equal, as it should be.Et si indiges uoluntate tua ad extensionem plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi pedem tuum: et ponas pedem super titillum inferius partem.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	If you cannot draw the end of the furcula outward: because it has retreated inward: then you must turn the patient backward over his neck; and place beneath his armpit a pillow of medium size, and have an assistant press his arm downward until the bone of the furcula which is inside moves upward; and then straighten the fracture and make it even with your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	If you feel a splinter in the furcula, and it moves, then you must search for it above it and extract it with ease.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	If it is retained inside the bone, then probe into the incision with one of your probes which you have prepared for this purpose after you have placed under the furcula the instrument that holds the sutures; and this instrument is of wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	It resembles a shallow spoon.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	Its breadth should be according to the size of the bone and its thinness.Et sit longitudinus eius quasi pedalis uncia una.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	Its length also, however, according to what is possible for you in the operation.Et sit concauitas eius ad modum concavitatis cochlearii, ut sic sithaca ossium ex omni parte repleatur, et per totum locum cohaereat: et secundum quod possit facere cum sutura.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	And have two extremities, as you see: and one extremity be broad, and the other narrow.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	If therefore the wound which thou didst split when thou didst draw out the splinter of bone, is broad, and thou hast seared it with a hot iron : then bring together the two lips of the wound with a suture.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	And if the split is small, or thou searest it with a hot iron: then fill up the wound with bandages and poultices according to the quantity of the split wound.Et si ossis scinditur in medio: imple uulnus cum pannis et puluillis, ut supra diximus.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	And if the bone be split in the midst: fill up the wound with bandages and poultices as we said above. And if thou searest it with a hot iron: then pour out an ointment made of rose-oil, vinegar and wine, and put it over the wound.Et si in medio ossis est uulnus, et scinditur ad extremitatem in qua ossis est angustus: tunc infunde olebrum super eum, et lege super ipsum pannum, et fac ut sithonia sit contra eum, et lega cum fascibus.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	A stricture of the bone when there is no wound and no cutting must be treated by placing on the bone a poultice made from flour with an egg white.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	And put a soft stopper over it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	Then place a ball under the tickling spot, if you need them.
