Deinde rade illud quod remanet in osse ex asperitate et corticibus minutis.	Then file that which remains in the bone from roughness and minute pieces of cortex.Et sit superius eius ad grossitudinem ex medietate eius usque ad inferiora.
Cum ergo reducitur os, et inuenit infirmus post reductionem eius dolorem uehementem laedentem, tunc scias, quod os non rediit ad locum suum naturalem.	When the bone is reduced and the infirm after its reduction finds very troublesome pain, then know that the bone has not returned to its natural place.Ergo oportet eum omnino reducere: siue cum eo quod diximus, siue etiam cum serris uis omnium potentissimus, et perfringere extremitatem illius ossis ad inferos: donec quando os reduxerit in locum suum naturalem.
Fac ergo illud.	Do therefore this.
Nam tu confers infirmo iuuamentum magnum, cum completur restauratio tua quam facis ossi.	For you bring to the sick person great relief when your remedy is applied to the bone.
Tunc submerge pannum in uino stiptico, nigro.	Then dip the cloth in astringent wine, the black.
Et proprie si est in aestate.	And if it is summer, especially.
Et non ponas super uulnus caerotum, neque aliquid in quo sit oleum: ut non faciat accidere in ipso putredinem et corruptionem.	And do not place anything on the wound that has oil in it, so that it does not cause putrefaction and corruption therein.
Deinde administra astellas in hora complementi tui a restauratione ossis.	Then give pills at the end of your restoration of the bone.
Et dimitte uulnus detectum: ita, ut incidas cum forficibus foramen in inuolutionibus secundum quantitatem uulneris.	And leave the wound uncovered, so that you cut an opening with forceps through the bandages according to the size of the wound.
Et caue omni cautela, ne stringas uulnus cum fractura.	And beware of every precaution, lest you bind up the wound with a fracture.
Multotiens enim fecerunt istud stolidi medici: et fecerunt accidere super infirmos suos aut mortem, aut corrosionem, aut zuchem, id est, saniem.	Many a time have foolish doctors done this and caused death or putrefaction or suppuration, that is, corruption to the sick.
Et sit strictura tua mollis, lenis, diuersa stricturae fracturarum reliquarum.	And let your bandage be soft and gentle and different from other fractures.
Quod si uulnus est malum, aut est uulnus magnum, et times super ipsum quaedam accidentia mala quae narrauimus, et inuenis dolorem in loco suspensum: tunc non oportet, ut ponas super ipsum astellas.	If the wound is bad or if it is a large wound, and you fear some evil accidents as aforesaid, and you find pain in the suspended place, then you ought not to put pills on it.
Et fac eis inuolutiones ex pannis duris in loco astellarum, et stringe ipsum cum eis.	And make bandages out of hard cloths in the place of pills and bind up the wound with them.Et si quod uulnus superius est clausum, nec potest aperiri, ponas super ipsum astellas, ne per uenturiam per totam carnem et ossa.
Cum autem est post diem unum, aut dies duos, et uides uulnus iam incipere, ut in eo generetur pus: tunc aufer desuper ipsum pannum quem posuisti super ipsum cum uino.	But if it is above and closed and cannot be opened, put pills over it lest through a vent through the whole flesh and bones. When however it is a day or two days later, and you see the wound already beginning to generate pus: then take away from above it the cloth which you put on it with wine.
Deinde administra licinia, et unguenta cum quibus de consuetudine nostra est, ut medicemur uulnera: sicut unguentum tetrapharmacon, et similia illi.	Then apply poultices and ointments with which it is our custom to heal wounds, such as the four-drug ointment and the like.Et fac illos stetere super uulnus, quousque videas pus subire in eis, aut eorum aliquid.
Et conuenit tibi, ut soluas ligamentum.	And let them remain over the wound until you see pus subsiding in them or some of them. And it is advisable that you loosen the bandages.
Et considera uulnus in omni die mane et uespere, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	And examine the wound every day in the morning and evening until it becomes hard and healed.
Et oportet, ut praeparetur membrum taliter, ut currat ex eo pus ad inferiora cum facilitate.	And it is necessary that the limb be prepared in such a way that pus flows out of it easily into the lower parts.
Quod si praetereunt uulneri dies multi, et non consolidatur, neque abscinditur pus ab eo: tunc scias, quod illic sunt satagie ossis parua.	If many days pass over the wound and it neither heals nor the pus is expelled from it, then know that there are small sores in the bone.
Quare oportet, ut inquiras uulnus cum tenta.	Wherefore you should probe the wound with a tent.
Quot uero ex illis alsatagie sunt separata, remoue ea, et extrahe ipsa.	As many as are separated sores, remove them and draw them out.
Et quae ex eis sunt non separata, et pungunt membrum, et faciunt accidere dolorem, conare incidere ea, et auferre ea omni modo quo possibile est tibi illud.	And those which are not separated and sting the limb and cause pain, try to cut them out and take them away in any way possible for you.
Quod si accidat uulneri zuchen, aut ekileten, id est, estiomenus, aut species alia corruptionis et putrefactionis: tunc oportet, ut opponas unicuique ex eis cum eo quod conuenit ei ex curatione, cuius praecessit narratio in capitulo suo.	If there happens to the wound a boil, or an ulcer, that is, slough, or another kind of putrefaction and corruption: then it is necessary to dress each one with whatever is proper for it according to what precedes in its chapter.Quo facto, si praesens sint ossa in uulnus, et non possit extrahi et omnes removi per tentas, et neque per tentam possit mussi et spongia intrare: tunc oportet, ut feceris ea omnia remouere per tentas.
Et ex eo in quo oportet ut stet sermo meus, et cui facias praesentem mentem tuam quando frangitur os, et eminet super membrum, sicut os coxae, et adiutorii, et similia eis ex membris magnis, est, ut non praesumas attractionem eius, multotiens enim accidit ex illo mors, imo dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat.	And from that in which my speech must stand, and to which you make present your mind when a bone is broken and sticks out above the limb, as in the case of the hip-bone, or helper-bone, or similar bones of the large limbs; it is not proper to assume attraction of it, for very often death happens from that, much rather let it be left, until it putrefies.
Fortasse enim cadet per se post uiginti dies, aut triginta.	For perhaps it will fall off by itself after twenty days or thirty.Et si non possit cadere per se, sed permanat stante, et tamen non debet exire, sed necesse est ut cadat, quod non posset cum tentis, sicut faciunt uulnera in ossibus pedum, aut manu: quare oportet, ut extrahas illud omni modo quo possibile sit.
Tunc ergo cura uulnus, si uidetur tibi: et sinon, dimitte ipsum.	And if it cannot drop off by itself but remains standing, and yet it should not come out, but needs must fall off, although it cannot with the probes as in wounds of the bones of feet or hand; then you must draw it out in any way possible.Then heal the wound when it seems to you: but if not, leave it alone.
¶ De curatione Nodationis in uestigio fracturae.	Of the cure of a nodation on a fracture.Et si accidat nodatio et putrefactio in medio fractura super os pedis, aut manu, aut adiuctorii: quare oportet, ut facias tentem latus, et profundum, ut possit intrare tentorium, donec attingat ossem, et intraiat ad medullam.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21.
Multoties accidit haec Nodatio in uestigio sanationis fracturae.	This nodule frequently occurs at the site of healing of a fracture.
Praecipue, quae est prope iuncturas: et foedatur ex ea figura membri.	Especially when it is near the site of the junction: and it is deformed from that figure of the limb.
Et fortasse prohibet membrum ab operatione sua naturali.	And perhaps it hinders the limb from its natural action.
Considera ergo tunc, si nodatio est recens: administra in ea medicinas quae stipticitatem habent, sicut aloe, et olibanum, et myrrha, et sarcocolla, et acacia, et similia eis.	Therefore consider then, if the nodule is recent: administer on it medicines which have astringency, such as aloes, and frankincense, and myrrh, and mucilage, and acacia, and similar to these.
Ita, ut accipias ex istis quasdam, aut omnes eas: et confice eas cum uino stiptico, aut cum albumine oui, aut cum aceto: et pone eas super nodationem in stuppa, et stringe eas super ipsam strictura bona.	Thus, that you may receive from these some or all of them: and make them with a styptic wine, or with white of egg, or with vinegar: and place them on the nodule in a sponge, and press them on it with a good compression.
Et dimitte stricturam, nec soluas eam diebus multis.	And leave the compression, and do not loosen it for many days.
Deinde solue eam, et itera aliam, donec remoueatur nodatio.	Then loosen it, and repeat another, until the nodule is removed.
Aut stringe super ipsam laminam plumbi decenter.	Or press on it decently a plate of lead.
Plumbo enim est proprietas remouendi omne quod timetur ex membris.	For lead has the property of removing all that is feared in limbs.
Si autem nodatio iam in lapidem conuersa est, et stricta est, et festine prouocat necessitas ad auferendum eam: tunc finde super eam ex superiori parte eius, et incide superfluitatem eminentem: aut rade eam cum quibusdam rasoriis, donec remoueatur: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	But if the nodule is now turned into stone, and is hard, and quickly the need presses to have it removed: then find on it from its upper part, and cut off the prominent surplus: or scrape it with some scrapers, until it is removed: and care for it, until it is healed.
¶ De curatione quando restauratur, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, non secundum naturam suam.	¶ Of the curing when it is restored, and the limb remains after that subtle, not according to its nature.Et si quaeritur cur in hac cura pluriuiolorum quorundam remediorum: quare haec nodatio remouatur:
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.
Quando restauratur fractura ossis, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, debile: tunc non fit illud nisi propter caussas multas.	When a bone is set and the limb remains thin and weak thereafter, then it does not occur except for many causes.
Quarum una est, multitudo solutionis ligamenti et ligationis eius non secundum quod oportet: aut propter superfluitatem stricturae ligamentorum, donec prohibeatur nutrimentum currere ad membrum: aut propter multitudinem embrocationis superfluae in non sua hora: aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore infirmi, et debilitatem eius.	One of which is, abundance of the solution of the ligament and its binding not according to what is appropriate; or because of the excess tightness of the ligaments, until it prevents nourishment from running to the limb; or because of the abundance of superfluous embrocation at an improper time; or because of lack of blood in the body of the sick person, and their weakness.
Et curatio illius est, cibare infirmum, et tenerum facere corpus eius, donec multiplicetur sanguis in eo.	And its treatment is to feed the sick person, and make his body tender until blood multiplies in him.Quam ob causam debet curari postea solutio ligamenti.
Et administra balneum.	And administer a bath.
Et intromitte gaudium et laeticiam super eum.	And bring joy and happiness to him.
Deinde pone picem super membrum: ut attrahat pix ad ipsum nutrimentum multum.	Then put pitch on the limb, so that the pitch may attract much food to itself.
Et assiduet embrocationem eius cum aqua tepida, donec currat nutrimentum, et redeat ad figuram suam naturalem.	And keep on rubbing it with warm water, until the food runs and returns to its natural shape.
¶ De curatione ossium fractorum quando restaurantur tortuose.	On the curing of broken bones when they are being restored crookedly.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter 23.
Quando accidit membro iam restaurato post sanationem eius tortuositas, et eminentia ossi fracto, aut nodatio: et foedatur per illud forma membri, uerumtamen membrum non prohibetur ab operatione sua naturali: tunc non oportet ut recipias sermonem eius, qui existimat, ut frangatur membrum denuo.	When the member already restored after its healing becomes crooked, and the bone sticks out or goes into a lump; and the form of the member is disgraced because of it, yet the member is not prohibited from performing its natural action: then you ought not to listen to him who thinks that the member should be broken again.
Et iam fuerunt multi stolidorum medicorum et restauratorum, qui fecerunt illud in terra nostra.	And there have already been many stupid physicians and restorers who have done this in our country.
Et haec quidem operatio est uituperabilis ualde, perducens ad mortem, uel timorem magnum, ut scilicet sit mortalis.	And indeed such an operation is very reproachful, leading to death or great fear, as indeed it is deadly.Et non debet esse facta in membrorum restauratis nisi per experientiam multorum annorum.
Verum si claudicatio et nodatio sunt recentes: tunc oportet, ut embrocetur cum aqua tepida, in qua decoctae sint herbae mollificantes, sicut folia alteae, et radix eius, et mellilotum, et illis similia.	But if the lameness and lump are recent: then it is fitting that you rub with warm water in which herbs that soften have been steeped, like alder leaves, and its root, and mayweed, and similar things.Et si est nuda claudicatio, et nodus non fit, sed solum claudicatio per ossa, tunc debet embrocari cum aqua tepida: et oportet ut ponas super locum, ubi claudicatio est: et debet inea faciem, et inea contrariam faciem.
Et fiat ei emplastrum cum emplastro mollificatiuo, sicut dyachilon decenter factum.	And if there is a naked lameness, and no lump but merely lameness through the bones, then it should be rubbed with warm water: and you ought to put on the place where the lameness is something that softens and makes smooth, such as dyachilon properly made.Et si exea claudicatio est in artus: et fit per ossa tortuositas, et per ea nodus, ut illum nodum concutiat: et si tamen ille non cadit nisi post multos mensas, et iterum retortur ad primam suam figuram: tunc debet esse facta illa operatio, sicut superius dictum est.
Aut sumatur mucilago radicis alteae, et concutiatur cum adipe gallinae, aut oleo sisamino: et emplastretur cum eo.	Or take the mucilage of the root of the marsh mallow plant and bruise it with chicken fat or sesame oil; then apply it as an ointment.
Aut sumantur ficus pingues, et terantur cum fimo columbino, et similibus eis quae nominantur ex medicinis diminuentes consolidationem.	Or take some figs and grind them down with dove dung and other similar ingredients named in medical texts as being useful for breaking down a hard swelling.
Et quandoque soluitur nodatio cum fricatione assidua, antiqua, et leni, quae fit cum manibus humidis.	Or the lump is dissolved by long-lasting, gentle rubbing with wet hands.
Et administretur motus membri ad omnem partem in horis omnibus.	And the limb should be moved to every part at all hours.
Si autem tortuositas iam antecessit, et fortis facta est, et conuersa est in lapidem, et prouocata est necessitas ad curatonem eius cum ferro: tunc oportet, ut secetur superius eius, et soluatur continuatio ossis, et incidatur quod superfluit ex nodatione aut osse cum Incisoriis subtilibus: et administretur facilitas in illo cum sollicitudine et studio.	But if the crookedness has already gone past that point and become stubborn and changed into stone, and the need for its cure has been brought about with iron, then it is appropriate to cut above it and dissolve the continuity of the bone, and cut away what protrudes from the swelling or bone with minute cutting instruments; and the relief in this should be administered with care and effort.
¶ De sermone in Dislocatione.	Of speech in dislocation.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Dislocatio est exitus alicuius iuncturarum a loco suo.	Dislocation is the exit of some joints from their proper place.Et habet quattuor signa principalia: scilicet, magnitudinem et durum et tortuosum et nodum.
Quare prohibetur a motu suo, et foedatur figura membri.	Therefore it is prohibited from its own movement, and the figure of the limb is marred.Et habet quaedam quae praecipua sunt: scilicet, tortuositas, et durum, et nodum, et magnitudinem.
Et facit accidere super infirmum dolores, et laesiones uehementes.	And it causes to happen over the weak pains and violent injuries.Et habet quaedam quae praecipua sunt: scilicet, tortuositas, et durum, et nodus, et magnitudinem.
Quando ergo accidit alicui dislocatio, tunc oportet festinare ad restaurationem eius: neque tardet eam omnino.	When therefore dislocation happens to anyone, then it is necessary to hurry about its restoration; nor should he delay it at all.Nam si tardet, et non curatur cum sollicitudine, tunc facit accidere super infimo dolores uehementes, et laesiones, et mortem: quia dislocatio est exitus alicuius iuncturarum a loco suo.
Nam si tardatur, apostematur locus, et fortasse cum eo reductio dislocationis.	If there is delay in healing, an abscess forms on the site of injury and with it perhaps a dislocation.
Propter illud ergo non oportet, ut moueatur, neque extendatur in hora apostemationis eius.	Therefore because of that it must not be moved or extended during the hour of the abscess. Nam si tardatur, apostematur locus, et fortasse cum eo reductio dislocationis.
Quoniam multotiens facit accidere spasmum, et dolores laedentes.	For often it brings about spasms and pains which are harmful. Nam apud alios quoque saepe convenit, ut ex illa parte pernicies in aliam trahatur.
Verum quando accidit illud, tunc oportet, ut properes ad phlebotomiam infirmi.	But when this happens then you must quickly apply bloodletting to the patient. Nam et perniciem facit multotiens cum dolore laedente.
Deinde dimittatur, donec quiescat apostema.	Then it is released until the abscess subsides. Et postea curanter appositione ligatur.
Deinde embrocetur membrum cum aqua calida et oleo.	Then the limb is fomented with warm water and oil. Postea autem uti debes, donec secundum suam naturem mende.
Deinde reducatur cum facilitate.	Thereafter you should proceed according to its natural course. Then the dislocation is reduced easily. Nam si pernicies adveniat, et non possit redux, ergo debet extendi in hora apostemationis eius.
Et curetur omne membrum cum eo cuius rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And cure every limb with that which comes to mind at the spot.
Ego quidem iam ordinaui capitula dislocationis, etiam secundum quod praecessit in fractura, a superiori parte corporis usque ad inferiorem eius.	I have indeed already arranged the chapters on dislocation, also according to what preceded on fracture, from the upper part of the body down to its lower part.
¶ De cura dislocationis Mandibulae inferioris.	¶ On the cure for dislocation of the lower jaw.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25.
Parum dislocantur duae Mandibulae nisi raro.	The two jaws are seldom displaced.
Et dislocatio ambarum fit secundum unum duoru modorum.	And the displacement of both happens in one of two ways.Quod si in medio sit, id non debet curari sed ad se redeundi patitur.
Aut enim remouentur a locis suis remotione parua, et mollificantur parumper.	Or they are moved from their places with a small movement and slightly relaxed.
Aut dislocantur dislocatione integra, completa, donec mollificentur ad partem pectoris, donec currat saliua infirmi, et non possit tenere eam, neque possit claudere os suum, et inuoluatur lingua eius cum sermone.	Or they are completely dislocated, a whole dislocation until they are relaxed to the chest part, until the patient runs freely, and he cannot hold it, nor can he close his bone, and his tongue is wrapped with speech.
Quando autem dislocatio eius est parua, tunc redit in pluribus dispositionibus per se cum paucitate.	But when its dislocation is small, then it returns to many dispositions by itself with little.
Si uero est dislocatio completa, integra: tunc oportet, ut administretur reductio eius uelociter, et non tardetur penitus: et est, ut teneat minister caput infirmi: et intromittat medicus pollicem manus suae unius in radicem Mandibulae dislocationis inter os eius, si dislocatio est a parte una.	But if it is a whole, complete dislocation: then the reduction of it must be administered quickly, and not be delayed thoroughly: and it is, that the assistant should hold the head of the patient: and the doctor should introduce the thumb of his one hand into the root of the mandible of the dislocation between his mouth, if the dislocation is on one side.
Aut intromittat duos pollices suos simul, si dislocatio est a duabus partibus.	Or he should introduce two thumbs simultaneously, if the dislocation is from two parts.Et tenens radicem dislocationis per se, trahat eam ad partem contrariam, usque donec ueniat in locum suum.
Et reliqui digiti manuum eius sint extra, quibus aequet.	And holding the root of the dislocation by itself, he will draw it to the contrary part, until it comes to its place. And the remaining fingers of his hand are out, which level it.
Et praecipe infirmo, ut mundificet Mandibulas suas, et absoluat eas ad manducandum ad omnem partem.	And tell the patient to cleanse his jaws and complete them for eating on all sides.Et praesentet ei bibere potum placidum et concupiscibile, cum aqua profusu, et non sit in ea sal.
Et medicus aequet Mandibulam, et impellat Mandibulam, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And the doctor levels the jaw and pushes the jaw until it returns to its place.Et si non possit redire per se, et non possit aduertere: tunc impellat illam per se medicus, cum manibus suis.
Quod si difficilis sit reductio eius, praecipue si sunt ambae Mandibulae simul: tunc administra uaporationem cum aqua calida, et oleo, donec fiat facilis reductio ambarum: neque tardes reductionem ambarum omnino, sicut diximus.	If its reduction is difficult, especially if both mandibles are together, then administer a vapouring with hot water and oil, until the reduction of both is easy. And do not delay the reduction of both at all, as we said.Et postea praecipere ei bibere potum placidum et concupiscibile ad libitum: quod uenerit cum salu: et praecipere ei per se mundificare Mandibulas suas.
Cum ergo redeunt et aequantur, et clauditur os infirmi, et non mollificantur: tunc pone super eas puluillos pannorum, cum ceroto quod sit factum ex cera: et oleo rosato.	When they return and are joined together and the mouth of the sick person is closed and not softened: then place on them a little cotton with a bandage that is made from wax: and rose oil.
Deinde ligetur cum facilitate cum ligamentis mollibus.	Then it shall be bound loosely with soft bandages.
Et sit somnus infirmi super dorsum suum: et caput eius sit stans inter duo puluinaria, ut non moueat ipsum ad dextram et sinistram: neque conetur, uel cogatur masticare aliquid: imo ponatur cibus eius sorbitio lenis, donec quando remouentur dolores, et nodatur Mandibula: tunc comedat quod uult, et administretur illud cum facilitate.	And let the sick person sleep on his back; and let his head be erect between two pillows, so that he may not move it to the right or left: neither shall he be choked, nor be forced to chew anything: nay, let his food be given him in a spoon, until such time as the pains are removed, and the jaw is loosed: then let him eat what he will, and let it be administered to him with ease.
Non laboret super operationem oris sui apud comestionem et potum, et oscitationem, donec nodetur Mandibula, et sanetur.	Let him not labour at the motion of his mouth in eating, drinking, and yawning, until the jaw be loosed and he be healed.
Quod si difficilis fiat reductio duarum Mandibuiarum, quando dislocantur in hora aliqua, et non conuertuntur ad loca sua: tunc multotiens accidunt inde febres, et soda assidua: et fortasse soluitur uenter infirmi, et fortasse uomit choleram puram.	If the return of the two jaws be difficult, when they are dislocated for a space of time, and are not brought back to their places: then often there arise from thence fever and constant vomiting; and perhaps the bowels of the sick person are loosed, and perhaps he vomits pure bile.
Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	When therefore thou seest this sign, know that it is a death-mark, and very often he who has it dies within ten days.
¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	Of the reduction of a dislocation of the collar-bone, and of the shoulder-joint.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26 (of book VI).Of the reduction of a dislocation of the collar-bone, and of the shoulder-joint.
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	The collar-bone is not dislocated from within, on account of its connexion with the breast.Et sic non debet puluare cum dislocatione.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	And it is dislocated sometimes outward, and this is discovered by feeling.Quod si autem dislocata sit in interioribus, et ex latere intrinseco: sic fit quod puluilex est os infirmi intra os puluilare.
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	And his restoration is that he lies on his back and extends his arms.
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	Then constrict the spot with your palm with a strong constriction, for it will return.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	Then place on it a plaster, and dust, and bind it tightly.
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	However, the extremities which follow the elbow, and are continuous with it, are not dislocated, except rarely.
Quod s dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	If anything is dislocated on some day, then it must be reduced and made equal according to what we have said, and what you prepare for yourself.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	Then place on it a plaster, and dust, and a bandage.
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	And prescribe to the patient adherence to tranquility and rest until he is healed.
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	And with this same treatment the extremity of the shoulder is reduced when it is also separated from its place.Et postea cum eodem modo reducuntur cunctae aliae dislocationes.
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	And afterwards with the same way all other dislocations are reduced.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27.
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	You should know that the shoulder is not dislocated except in three ways.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	Of which one is, to be dislocated towards the side of tickling towards the lower part.Et alterus ad superiora et contraria via.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	And the second is, to be dislocated towards the side of the chest.Et tertius ad partem dorsi.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	And perhaps it is dislocated to the upper portion of the Humerus; and that occurs rarely.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	And it is not dislocated to the posterior, because of the spatula.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	And it is not dislocated to the anterior, because of the nerve.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	Indeed, most often it dislocates and slips out towards the lower side of the joint; especially with those whose flesh is thin.
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	Because it slips into them quickly and enters quickly.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	But with those whose flesh is abundant, the contrary of that happens, namely because it slips out with difficulty and enters with difficulty.Quod si dislocatur ad superiora uel posteriora uel anteriora, multum doloris accidit in eis.
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	And if it dislocates to the upper or posterior or anterior side, much pain happens in them. And perhaps some men suffer a blow or fall and the Humerus is pustulated by a hot pustule, and it is thought because of that, that indeed it is dislocated already.Et non est propter illud dislocatus: sed per se apostematum est apostemate calido.
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	You should therefore try it out until you are sure of it, and then proceed to cure it.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	And a dislocation is known when it is turned towards the lower part of the tickling; and you must distinguish between a dislocated shoulder and a healthy one.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	For you find a manifest difference between them, and you find a concavity on the head of the shoulder, and below the tickling place near to the touch of the head of the shoulder as if it were hollow; and the sick person cannot bring his hand to his ear, nor move it in any movements.
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	And similarly, if it is dislocated turned towards the breast, or upwards: then you find a manifest touch, and it does not hide.
Et huius quidem dislocationis fit facilis reductio, quando est recens, aut infirmus est puer.	And this kind of dislocation is easily reduced when it is recent, or the patient is an infant.
Et reductio eius est, ut eleuet minister manum suam ad superiora.	And its reduction is that the assistant lifts his hand upwards.
Deinde pone tu pollices tuos sub titillico eius, et eleua iuncturam cum fortitudine ad sursum ad locum suum: et minister eleuet manum suam, et extendat eam ad sursum.	Then put your thumbs under his tickling place, and raise the joint strongly upwards to its place; and the assistant lifts up his hand and extends it upwards.
Deinde ponat eam inferius, ipse enim redit uelociter.	Then let him bring it down again, for it returns quickly of itself.
Si autem non redit per illud quod diximus, et sunt a principio quo accidit dislocatio dies multi: tunc oportet, ut balneetur infirmus in aqua calida, et administretur embrocatio quae mollificat et lenit, sicut si decoquantur radices alteae, et foenugraecum, et mellilotum in aqua, et administretur.	But if it does not return by that which we have said above, and many days are passed since the dislocation happened: then the sick person must be bathed in warm water, and embrocation must be applied which softens and soothes, as if they were boiling roots of alexanders, and fenugreek, and melilot in water, and it is applied.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et ponatur sub titillico eius sphera et lana, quae sit aequalis inter lenitatem et stricturam.	Then let the sick person lie on his back: and put under his tickling place a ball and wool, which is equal between mildness and tightness.
Deinde ponat medicus calcaneum suum super spheram, et eleuet caput humeri cum uirtute, et attrahat manum infirmi ad inferiora.	Then let the doctor put his heel over the ball, and raise the head of the shoulder with strength, and draw the hand of the sick person downwards.
Et minister alius teneat caput infirmi, ut non moueatur ad inferiora: ipse namque redit statim.	And another assistant hold the head of the sick person, so that it does not move downwards; for it returns immediately by itself.
Et si uis, reduc eum secundum modum hunc: et est, ut facias esse praesentem uirum qui sit longior infirmo, et stet a parte lateris, et intromittat humerum suum sub titillico infirmi: et eleuet titillicum eius ad superiora, donec sit infirmus suspensus in aere.	And if you wish, reduce it according to this method: and it is, that you make the man who is longer be present with the sick person, and stand aside, and introduce his humerus under the armpit of the sick person; and lift his armpit up towards the higher parts, until the sick person is suspended in the air.
Et minister alius trahat manum infirmi ad inferiora uentris eius.	And another servant should pull the hand of the sick person down towards his lower abdomen.
Si autem infirmus est leuis: tunc oportet, ut suspendatur cum eo aliquid aliud, ut grauet ipsum: nam redit dislocatio statim.	But if the sick person is light: then something else should be hung on him to add weight, for the dislocation returns at once.
Et reducitur etiam secundum modum alium: et est, ut figatur in terra lignum longum, cuius caput sit rotundum figura: sicut manica mortarii: quod non sit grossum, neque subtile.	And it is also reduced according to another method: and it is, that a long wood is fixed into the ground, whose end is round in shape: like the bottom of a mortar: which is not thick, nor thin.Et ponantur pedes eius sub titillico infirmus: et intromittantur omnes digiti titilli sub capite ligni: et eleuant titillum ad superiora.
Deinde ponatur sub infirmo postquam ponuntur super caput ligni panni lenes: et infirmus sit stans secundum longitudinem ligni.	Then place it under the patient after they have been laid on top of a soft wooden board: and let the patient be standing according to the length of the wood.
Deinde extendatur manus eius ad inferiora a parte altera, et extendatur corpus eius ab altera parte cum fortitudine: nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then his hand is stretched out to the lower part on the other side, and his body is stretched with force from the other side: for the joint returns to its place with speed.
Quod si difficilis sit eius reductio per omnia quae diximus, tunc utere hac cura: et est, ut accipias lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum, et eius latitudo quantitas quatuor digitorum, et grossitudo eius quantitas duorum digitorum: cui sit caput rotundum, ut alleuietur introitus eius in profundum titillici, secundum hanc formam.	If its return through all that we have said is difficult, then use this care: and it is, that you take wood whose length is the quantity of two cubits, and whose breadth is the quantity of four fingers, and whose thickness is the quantity of two fingers: to which let there be a round head, so that its entrance into the deep tickling may be eased, according to this form.
Deinde ligentur super caput rotundum panni lenes, ut non laedat lignum infirmum.	Then soft rags are tied over the round head, so that it does not hurt the wooden patient.Postquam autem ponuntur super caput panni lenes et super linea ligna, deinde ponatur sub infirmo sacculus lanarius per omnes articulaciones: sed non tantum ut laeda ligneum, verum etiam ut possit movere articulaciones per omnes partes.
Deinde ponatur sub titillico infirmi, ut extendatur manus, aut brachium super lignum usque ad inferiora: et ligetur lignum super adiutorium et brachium et extremitatem manus.	After the soft rags and the wooden board have been placed on top of the round head, then a woolen sack is placed under the patient's tickling so that it extends his hand or arm over the wood to the lower part: and the wood is tied over the helper and the arm and the end of the hand.Et sic ambulando per omnes partes titillico, ligatur in omni parte ut viderit adflictum.
Deinde ponatur brachium super gradum scalae per latitudinem, et extendatur manus ad inferiora, et dimittatur reliquum corpus suspensum a parte altera.	Then let the arm be placed across the width of the steps of the ladder, and let the hand be extended downward, and let the rest of the body hang from the other side.
Iunctura enim ingreditur statim.	For the joint immediately goes in.
Cum ergo completur introitus eius secundum quemcunque modum possibile est: tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico spheram aequalis quantitatis ex lana.	When therefore its entrance is completed in whatever way possible: then you must place under the foreskin a sphere of equal quantity made of wool.
Deinde pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum olibano, et albumine oui super humerum totum, sicut reuoluitur desuper.	Then place the plaster prepared from mill-dust with frankincense and egg white all over the shoulder, as far as it is exposed above.
Deinde stringe sub titillico strictura decenti: et reuoluatur ligamentum super emplastrum desuper: et annectatur manus eius ad collum ipsius, et dimittatur, neque moueatur manus eius septem diebus.	Then tighten the ligature under the foreskin decently: and let the bandage be wound over the plaster above: and let his hand be attached to his neck, and let him be left so, and his hand not moved for seven days.
Et oportet, ut ponatur cibus infirmipaucus, donec confortetur membrum: quoniam est uelocius ad sanationem eius.	And it is necessary that a light diet be given until the limb is strengthened: because it is swifter to its recovery.
Deinde ponatur amplior post septem dies, aut quinque, et ex ercitetur cum motu.	Then after seven days or five, let him be roused with movement.
Si ergo firmatur et non mollificatur, tunc iam sanatus est.	If therefore it is strengthened and not softened, then he is healed already.In uulnera quae fiunt super caput ossis: ponantur super eum emplastra, donec colligat.
Si uero iunctura dislocatur multotiens, propter humiditatem quae accidit ei, aut propter caussam aliam: tunc oportet, ut administretur in ea cauterium cum tribus foraminibus, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo de cauterio.	If however the joint is often dislocated, because of the moisture that comes to it, or for some other cause: then cautery must be applied to it with three punctures, as was said before in the chapter on cautery.Et si uelocius resecatur iunctura per cauterium, et colligatur, et non mollificatur post tres dies aut quinque, et durescat: tunc oportet, ut molienda puluis millini cum olibano et teriatur, et fiat puluere.
Quod si fiat hoc totum, et soluatur ligamentum post septem dies, et non confirmetur iunctura, et reducatur emplastrum et strictura super ipsum aliquotiens, et non firmetur, et cadat, et non possit eleuare ipsum ad superiora: tunc scias, quod nerui eius qui sunt ad caput humeri, iam incisi sunt, aut extensi, aut mollificati: et scias, quod iunctura nunquam figetur in loco suo.	If the joint is cut through by cautery and bound together and not softened after three or five days, and hardens: then let the mill-dust be ground with frankincense, and made into powder.Now if this is all done, and the ligature is loosed after seven days, and the joint is not strengthened, and the bandage and ligature are taken off from it often, and it is not firmed up, and falls down, and cannot be raised to the upper [position]: then know that the nerves which are on the head of the humerus, are now cut through, or stretched, or softened: and know that the joint will never set in its place.
Dislocationis autem quae fit uersus pectus et mammillam, aut ad posteriora reductio, fit cum impulsione et extensione cum manibus: donec redeat, et administretur in ea reliqua strictura et cura, donec sanetur.	And for dislocation which is turned towards the chest and breast, or back, is done with push and extension by hand until it returns to its place; then apply the remaining compression and treatment until healed.
Quod si accidat post sanationem grauitas in membro, et tarditas in motu eius, tunc utatur infirmus balneo multotiens, donec leniatur illa grauitas, et redeat ad naturam eius primam.	And if it happens that there is heaviness in the limb after healing and slowness of movement in it, then the invalid should use a bath many times, until that heaviness is relieved, and back to its original nature.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Cubiti.	About curing dislocation of the elbow:
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter 28.
Scias, quod iunctura Cubiti dislocatur cum difficultate, et similiter redit cum difficultate etiam: et ipsa quidem dislocatur ad omnes partes, et praecipue ad anteriorem, aut ad posteriorem.	Know that the joint of the elbow is dislocated with difficulty, and likewise returns with difficulty; and indeed it is dislocated to all parts, especially to the front or back.De dislocatione Cubiti.
Et eius dislocatio non occultatur tibi: quoniam est cadens sub uisu, et sub tactu, secundum quamcunque figuram dislocetur.	And its dislocation is not hidden from you; because it is under sight and under touch, according to whatever figure it is dislocated.De signis dislocationis Cubiti.
Et quando coniungis cubitum dislocatum cum sano, declaratur tibi illud manifeste.	And when you join the dislocated elbow with a healthy one, that is made clear to you.De dislocatione humeri.
Concauatur enim iunctura, et non potest duplicare brachium, neque tangere cum eo humerum suum.	For the joint is concave, and cannot bend double the arm, nor touch it with its shoulder.Of the dislocation of the shoulder.De dislocatione scaphorum.
Et oportet, ut properes, et reducas dislocationem statim, antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And you should hasten to reduce the dislocation immediately before a hot blister occurs in it.Of the dislocation of the jaw.De dislocatione Mandibulae.
Nam si accidit ei apostema calidum, difficilis fit eius reductio: et fortasse non sanatur omnino, praecipue quando est ad posteriora.	For if a hot blister occurs in it, its reduction is difficult; and perhaps it is not healed at all, especially when turned to the back.Of the dislocation of the jaw.De dislocatione ossis nasalis.
Est enim deterior omnibus speciebus dislocationis, et uehementioris doloris eis: et multotiens descendit cum ea mors.	For this is the worst of all dislocations, and causes more severe pain to them; and death often comes with it.Of the dislocation of the nasal bone.De dislocatione ossis occipitis.
Et restauratio eius quando est ex eis quae possibile est reducere, est, ut extendatur manus eius cum duabus manibus: et brachium eius sit expansum, et manus medici sint supra cubitum et sub eo, et ipse impellat iuncturam cum pollicibus manuum suarum simul, aut cum radice palmae suae, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And its restoration when it is one of those that can be reduced, is to extend the hand with two hands; and let the arm be outstretched, and the physician's hands be above the elbow and below it, and he push the joint with the tips of his thumbs simultaneously or with the root of his palms, until it returns to its place.Of the dislocation of the occipital bone.De dislocatione ossis quae sunt sub naso.
Aut uero dislocatio est ad anteriora: tunc redit ita, ut duplicet manum cum manu sua, donec percutiat cum radice palmae suae cubitum qui est dislocatus.	Or if it is a displacement towards the front: then he reduces it by doubling his hand over his own hand until he strikes with the root of his palm the elbow that is displaced.
Quod si non obedit dislocatio ad reductionem, tunc administra extensionem uehementem, fortem ualde: et est, ut extendant brachium duo ministri: et teneant ipsum duo ministri etiam, ut non remoueatur apud extensionem.	If the displacement does not yield to reduction then you must apply a strong and forceful extension, and two assistants must extend both arms and two other assistants must also hold it so that it may not move at the time of the extension.
Deinde reuoluatur brachium ad omnem partem postquam inuoluitur super manum eius pannus duplicatus longus, aut ligamentum latum.	Then the arm is turned in all directions after having wrapped a long folded cloth or wide bandage around his hand.
Et quando tangit medicus manu sua iuncturam, inungat ipsam cum oleo: ut sit illud ex eis quae adiuuant in lubricitate iuncturae cum facilitate.	And when the doctor touches the joint with his hand he should anoint it with oil so that it is among those things that help to lubricate the joint with ease.
Deinde impellat iuncturam impulsione uehementi, donec redeat.	Then he must push on the joint with a forceful blow until it comes back into place.
Et post reductionem eius oportet, ut ponatur super ipsam emplastrum, in quo sit stipticitas, et exiccatio cum albugine oui: et stringatur strictura decenti.	And after its reduction it is necessary that a plaster be applied over it in which there is stinginess, and drying with white powder: and it must be bound tight with a suitable bandage.
Et suspendatur brachium a collo infirmi: et dimitte diebus aliquot.	And the arm of the patient should be suspended from his neck for several days.
Deinde soluatur.	Then, afterwards, it should be loosened.
Si ergo firmatur iunctura in loco suo, tunc solue ligamentum ab ea, et dimitte ipsam.	If, however, the joint is firmly set in its place, then loosen the bandage from it and leave it.Et si non obedit dislocatio, sed remouet ad loca pernicieua: et ualet pro dislocatione in extremum, et non reducatur, tunc teneatur eadem modo sicut prius dislocata est, et trahatur ad omnes partes.
Et si uides iuncturam non bene stringi, tunc itera emplastrum, et ligamentum, et dimitte ipsam diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	And if you see that the suturing is not well tied, then repeat the ointment, and the ligature, and leave it for several days, until it is tied.
Deinde solue ipsam.	Then cut it.
Si autem accidit ei grauitas post reductionem iuncturae, et dispositio sit in motu: tunc administra humectationem in balneatione, et fricationem subtilem, et compressionem, donec liniatur, aut pone super iuncturam iliati, id est, natem arietis pinguem.	But if there is a swelling after the suturing is reduced and the part moved: then apply a poultice in a bath, and a gentle friction, and compression until it is soothed, or put on the joint, that is, fat of ram.
Deinde ligetur, et dimitte ipsam super eam die et nocte.	Then let it be tied, and leave it on for one day and night.Et si accidat in iunctura ulceratio, et pus: ponendo super eam emplastrum subtile de lino, et radice silii, et malva, et mallow, et cumina, et creta, et aqua.
Deinde aufer eam, et intromitte ipsum in balneum.	And if there is an ulcer in the suturing, and pus: put on a poultice of fine flax, and the root of mustard, and mallows, and mallows, and cumin, and chalk, and water.Then take it off, and put it into a bath.Et si sit ad modum ulceris, et pussit: tunc aufer eam per paucos dies, donec sit curata.
Cum ergo sudat, tunc frica iuncturam fricatione temperata.	Then when it sweats, then rub the joint with a tempered friction.
Deinde itera super ipsam aleliati uice una, et secunda, et tertia cum introitu balnei, donec leniatur.	Then repeat over it with the ointment once, and twice, and thrice at the time of bathing, until it is soothed.
Et si uis, pone super ipsam stercus uaccinum, humidum, calefactum cum butyro, et stringe super ipsum.	And if you will, place over it a poultice of cow dung, moistened and warmed with butter, and bind it over it.
Fac illud aliquotiens.	Do this several times.Et si non possis intrare balneum, fac te sudare in domo tua, et pone super ipse uaccinum.
Ipsa namque lenitur, et redit ad dispositionem suam.	And if you cannot go into the bath, make yourself sweat in your own house and put the poultice over it.It soothes itself, and returns to its natural state.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Almahassem.	Of the cure of a dislocation, by Albucasis.Si ergo dislocatus est humervs, vel quaeue parte corporis dislocata sit, omnia prima fac ut sudet valde; et cum sudaverit, tunc fricatione temperata frigescat, nec super ipso tangas.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter 29.Of the cure of a broken bone.Si itaque fractus fuerit humerus vel quaeue parte corporis fracta sit, fac ut sudet valde; et cum sudaverit, fricatione frigescat, et super locum fracti tangas.
Mahassem manus multotiens dislocatur, id est, iunctura quae est inter brachium et manum.	The joint between the arm and the hand is frequently dislocated, that is, the joint which is between the arm and the hand.Cum itaque dislocata sit Mahassem, intra et extra balneum sic curari debet.
Et reductio dislocationis eius est facilis.	And when it has been dislocated, it should be thus cured within and without the bath.And its reduction is easy.Postea itaque cum introitu balnei fricationem temperatam fac super locum dislocationis, et iterum post sudatum; et sic iterum tertia vice.
Econtrario reliquarum iuncturarum.	Then afterwards with the entrance into the bath make a tempered friction over the place of the dislocation, and again after it has sweated, and thus for the third time.But do the contrary for other joints.Et postea cum introitu balnei fac ut sudet valde, et post sudatam fricationem fac super locum dislocationis, donec leniatur; et iterum cum sudaverit, iterum fricare.
Verumtamen oportet, ut uelocitas sit in reductione dislocationis eius in hora in qua dislocatur, antequam apostemetur locus: aut accidat in eo apostema calidum.	And afterwards with the entrance into the bath make it sweat profusely, and after sweating make a friction over the place of the dislocation until it is soothed; and again when it has sweated, make a friction again.But it behooves that swiftness be in the reduction of its dislocation within the hour in which it was dislocated, before any apostemation takes place in the joint: or let there happen in it a warm apostemation.Et si ergo non possis intrare balneum, fac ut sudet in domo tua anteque intrantes balneum fricationem fac super locum dislocationis, et postea cum introitu balnei iterum fricare debes.
Et reductio dislocationis in eo est, ut ponas Mahassem manus infirmae super tabulam, et extendat minister manum eius: et ponat medicus palmam suam super eminentiam iuncturae, et impellat eam, donec redeat.	And the reduction of a dislocation is such that one places the hand of the patient with the weakness on a board, and one extends the hand; and the physician puts his palm over the area of the joint and pushes until it returns to its position.
Verumtamen oportet, ut consyderetur, si palma iam recessit ad uentrem manus: tunc ponat infirmus dorsum manus suae super tabulam apud extensionem et reductionem: et si dislocatio est procedens ad dorsum manus, tunc sit positio manus eius intrinsece super tabulam, id est, interior pars manus eius super tabulam ponatur, ut cadat manus medici super ipsam eminentiam iuncturae.	However, one must consider if the palm is already facing inwards towards the wrist: then the patient places the back of his hand upon the board by the extension and reduction; and if the dislocation is going towards the back of the hand, then the position of the hand is reversed on the board, that is, the inner part of the hand is placed upon the board so that the hand of the physician falls over the area of the joint.
Si ergo redit statim, bonum est: et si non, tunc stringe eam cum emplastro sedante apostema: et dimitte ipsum, neque iteres illud.	If therefore it returns at once, it is well; and if not, then bind it with a soothing plaster; and let it be, and do not repeat the procedure.
Nam si non tolerat, neque potes super reductionem eius, postquam praetereunt ei dies, uerumtamen iunctura remanet secundum tortuositatem suam: et non nocet infirmo aliquid, nisi quod mollificatur manus, et non potest stringere aliquid: tunc scias, quod nerui sunt abscissi, aut attriti.	For if he cannot tolerate it and you are not able to place the joint right again after he has walked for a few days, then the joint will remain in its crookedness; and it does no harm to the patient except that his hand is weakened and he cannot grasp anything; then you may know that some of the nerves are severed or worn away.
Non est ergo ingenium in ea, nisi ut stringatur cum cauterio prope casum eius.	There is therefore no skill in it except to bind it with a ligature close to where it is dislocated.
Et fortasse non confert illud aliquid.	And perhaps it accomplishes nothing.
Cum ergo non redit Almahassem, tunc pone super ipsum emplastrum, quod narrauimus.	When therefore the hand does not return to its position, then place over it a soothing plaster, as we have described.
Deinde stringatur, et dimittatur quinque diebus: postea soluatur et dimittatur, et exercitetur manus.	Then let it be bound and left for five days; afterwards let it be loosed and left, and the hand exercised.
Si autem priuatur motus eius, et accidat in ea aliquid grauitatis: tunc leni eam cum aqua calefacta, et fricatione aliquotiens, donec leniatur.	But if its movement is restricted and something of heaviness occurs in it, then make it warm with hot water and rub it frequently, until it becomes flexible.Et si postea redit ad locum suum, bene; sin autem non redeat: tunc ponatur super tabulam, et stringatur cum ligatura prope eminenti iuncturae, et dimittatur: et per quod diem iteret, totus dies exercitetur.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Digitorum.	Of the cure for dislocation of the fingers.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Quando dislocatur ex eis Digitus ad omnem partem, uel ex eis Digitus ad dorsum palmae, aut uentrem eius: tunc extende Digitum, et impelle dislocationem pollicibus tuis, donec redeat.	When a finger is dislocated to every part from these fingers, or from these fingers to the back of the palm, or the hollow of it; then extend the finger, and force the dislocation with your thumbs, until it returns.
Deinde sustenta caput Digiti, et suspende ipsum uersus partem ad quam dislocatur, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	Then sustain the head of the finger, and suspend it turned towards the part to which it is dislocated, and let it go for two days.De curatione luxationis Cubiti.
Deinde suspende eum, et extende ipsum, donec aequetur rectus in illo die suo.	Then suspend him and stretch him out until he is straight on that day.
Cum ergo fuerit nox, liga ipsum secundum narrationem ipsam: et non cesses soluere ipsum in die: et exerce eum cum motu: et liga ipsum in nocte.	When therefore it becomes night, bind him according to the same account; and do not cease to loosen him by day; and exercise him with motion; and bind him at night.
Fac illud diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	Do that for a few days until he is tightened.
Et similiter fac cum eo, si dislocatur ad uentrem manus: et liga eum ad partem ipsam, et fac cum eo operationem tuam primam, donec sanetur.	And likewise do with him, if he be dislocated in the belly: and bind him to that part, and do to him your first operation until he is healed.
Et similiter fac cum eo quando dislocatur ad reliquas partes.	And likewise do with him when he is dislocated to other parts.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Spondilium dorsi.	¶ Of the cure of a dislocation of the vertebrae of the back.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Quando accidit alicui Spondilium dorsi, aut colli dislocatio completa, aut remouentur Spondiles multae a locis suis: tunc non est in ea curatio, quoniam mors properat infirmo.	When it happens to anyone that a vertebra of the back or neck is completely dislocated, or the vertebrae are greatly removed from their places, then there is no cure for it, because death is hastening on the invalid.Et si dislocatio non sit completa: prima res est, ut remouentur Spondiles a locis suis: quod faciunt Spondiliaci, cum caput alicuius in placitum est, et remouent eum manibus ad latera.
Et signum illius est, quod egestio infirmi egreditur absque uoluntate, neque potest tenere eam: et multotiens mollificantur ex eo quaedam membra eius, aut duo crura eius, aut duo brachia ipsius, aut unum eorum: aut remouetur Spondilis una de loco suo.	And if the dislocation is not complete, first let them remove the vertebrae from their places; this they do to a man whose head is in that condition, by moving him with their hands to the sides.And its sign is, that some of his limbs, or two of his legs, or two of his arms, or one of them, are often benumbed from it, or the vertebra is removed from its place.Et si remouentur totus Spondiles de locis suis: et ego non ostenderim tibi uocem illam, quae facit dislocationem illam, sed remouet totos Spondiles a locis suis: primum tenendo eum per caput: et si non possit teneri: tunc manibus remouent eum ad omnia latera.
Multotiens enim remouetur, quod multotiens fit remotio earum ad quatuor partes.	For it is often removed, for that removal of these parts is often made into four parts.
Illa ergo quae remouetur ad posteriora, nominatur Gibbositas.	And so that which is removed to the posterior, is named Gibbositas.
Curatio uero eius est, ut consyderes tunc, si Gibbositas accidit a puericia: tunc non est in ea curatio, neque ex ea est sanatio omnino.	But its treatment is that you consider if Gibbositas happens from childhood; then there is no treatment for it, nor from it is there any healing at all.
In illa autem quae accidit a casu, aut percussione, aut similibus illis, iam dixerunt antiqui modos curationis sermone prolixo.	But the ancients have already said ancient modes of curing with prolix speech about those which happen from chance, or a blow, or similar to these.
Cuius plurimum non redit cum proficuo.	Of which there is no return with profit.
Ego uero iam abbreuiaui ex illo, cuius parum excusat a multo eius ex propinquitate mea ad intentionem: et expositione mea qua exposui illud, et formaui instrumentum eius diuerso modo ab eo quo ostenderunt illud, et exposuerunt ipsum.	I have indeed already abridged from that, whose little excuses from much of its proximity to my intention: and by my exposition about which I have exposed it, and formed its instrument in a different way from that in which they presented it, and exposed it itself.
Dico ergo, quod in gibbositate quae accidit ab anteriori parte, non est ingenium, neque sanatio ex ea.	I say then, that there is no nature in Gibbositas which happens from the anterior part, nor healing from it.
Et similiter in illa quae fit ad duo latera etiam.	And similarly also in that which is made to two sides.
Et non curatur ex eis, nisi illa quae accidit in dorso proprie, cum eo quod ego narro: et est, ut extendatur infirmus super faciem suam super podium aequale prope parietem: et expandatur sub eo stramentum humidum, ut non laedatur pectus eius.	And they are not healed from these, unless that which happens in the back properly, with what I narrate and is, so that the infirm may be extended over its face over an even podium near a wall: and expand under it wet bedding, so that his breast does not become hurt.
Deinde ponatur lignum rectum fixum in fouea in terra, in extremitate podii, circiter caput eius: et lignum aliud circiter pedes eius in extremitate altera podii: et minister teneat lignum, et sit non firmatum in fouea.	Then let a straight fixed board be placed in the pit on earth, at the end of the podium around its head; and another wood around its feet at the other end of the podium; and a minister should hold the wood, and it not be firmly placed in the pit.
Et minister alter teneat alterum.	And another minister should hold the other.
Deinde inuolue super caput infirmi, et sub titillicis eius ligamentum lene, firmum: et extende extremitatem ligamenti ad lignum quod est apud caput eius: et liga ipsum in eo.	Then wrap over the head of the infirm, and under its chin a soft, firm ligament; and extend the end of the ligament to the wood which is at its head; and tie it in that.
Deinde stringe ligamentum aliud supra anchas eius, et supra genua ipsius, et apud cauillas eius.	Then tighten another ligament over his hips, and over his knees, and at his shins.Et ponatur super titillas eius, quae in fronte sunt, pera vna luta.
Deinde aggrega ligamenta omnia, et liga ea in ligno altero quod est apud pedes eius.	Then bring together all the ligaments and tie them with a wood that is at his feet.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem ligni ligamentum, et non remoueantur duo ligna ex locis suis in quibus sunt fixa: uerumtamen non sint firmata, sicut diximus.	Then all the ministers should go to the side of the wood that has the ligaments and not move the two woods from their places where they are fixed; but they must not be tightened as we have said.
Et medicus ponat palmas suas super Spondilem cum fortitudine, donec redeat: aut ponat super eam tabulam.	And the doctor should put his hands with strength on the vertebra until it returns to place; or he should put a board on top of it.
Deinde annectat super tabulam pedes suos, donec redeat.	Then he should attach his feet above the board until it returns to its place.
Si autem non redit per hanc curationem, tunc accipe tabulam cuius longitudo sit circiter tria brachia.	If it does not return with this treatment, then take a board whose length is about three cubits.Et ponat eam sub ligatura, quod siueum sit in medio, et ubi sint pedes ligatur.
Et caua in pariete de quo diximus quod est prope infirmum, locum in quem ingrediatur extremitas tabulae.	And make an incision in the wall of which we said is near the invalid, the location into which the end of the board enters.
Deinde pone medium tabulae super Spondilem.	Then place the middle of the board over the spine.
Et ponat pedes suos medicus super extremitatem alteram.	And let the doctor put his feet on the other end.
Et stringat bene, donec coartetur Spondilis, et redeat ad locum suum.	And it is well bound until the spine is contracted and returns to its place.
Deinde si uis, operare cum torno quod inuoluitur cum manu tua: et est, ut figas in terram apud caput infirmi in postremo podii duo ligna, quorum longitudo sit brachii unius: et apud caput eius in postremo podii duo ligna.	Then if you wish, operate with a lathe which is wrapped with your hand: and it is as if you fix in the ground near the head of the invalid at the end of the foot two pieces of wood, whose length is a cubit one: and near his head at the end of the foot two pieces of wood.
Et sit longitudo quae est inter omne lignum palmus unus: et iam factum est in omni loco foramen, in quo currit tornum: et firmetur lignum omne in terra multum, ne moueatur omnino.	And let the distance between each piece of wood be a palm: and now it is made in every place a hole, through which the lathe runs; and the wood is firmly fixed in the ground a lot, so that it does not move at all.
Et intromittatur lignum rotundum: et est tornum in quo reuoluitur ligamentum in duobus foraminibus duorum lignorum.	And a round wood is inserted: and the lathe in which the ligament revolves in the two holes of the two pieces of wood.
Et in extremitate eius est foramen, in quo firmatur lignum, cuius longitudo est palmus cum eo quod reuoluitur: et in duobus lignis aliis est similiter illius.	And at its end is a hole, in which the wood is secured, whose length is a palm with that which revolves; and in the other two pieces of wood it is similarly of this.
Deinde stringe ligamenta quae strinxisti in pectore infirmi torno quod est apud caput eius: et ligamenta quae strinxisti in cruribus eius in torno quod est apud pedes eius.	Then tighten the ligaments which you tied on the chest of the invalid with the lathe which is at his head; and the ligaments which you tied on his thighs with the lathe which is at his feet.Et si non possit tollere se in locum suum, ponant eum super pedes et crura, quos posuerat ante, donec possit tollere se in locum suum.
Deinde stet apud omne tornum minister, qui torqueat manum suam cum licinio, cum quo reuoluitur tornum: et medicus aequet Spondilem, secundum quod diximus.	Then let each assistant stand by the turnbuckle, holding his hand with a linen cloth, by which the turnbuckle is wound; and the physician shall apply the spondylos according to what we have said.
Haec est forma torni, quae sequitur.	This is the form of the turnbuckle that follows:
Deinde postquam redit Spondilis, et aequatur locus, tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum exiccatiuum cum albumine oui.	Then after the spondylos has been returned and the place made even, it is proper to put on a plaster of dried egg white.
Deinde stuppam.	Then the tampon.
Postea pone supra emplastrum astellam ex tabula, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, aut circiter eos.	Next place above the plaster a strip of wood table, whose breadth is three fingers, or about that.
Et longitudo eius quantitas quae capiat locum Gibbositatis, et super partem Spondilis sanae.	And its length as much as will fit the space of the herniated gibbosity and on top of the healthy part of the spondylos.
Deinde ligetur cum ligamento quod diximus.	Then it is to be bound with a bandage as we have said.
Et utatur infirmus nutrimento subtili, donec sanetur.	And the invalid should use light food until he recovers.
Quod si remaneat quiddam eminentiae in loco in fine sanationis: tunc oportet, ut administrentur medicinae quae mollificant, et leniunt, cum administratione tabulae quam narrauimus tempore longo.	If at the end of healing something still remains prominent in the place, then it is proper to administer medicines which soften and smooth out with application of the table of which we have spoken for an extended time.
Et iam administratur in illo lamina plumbi.	And now a leaf of lead is administered.
Et quandoque accidit eminentia in postremo Spondilium dorsi: et putatur per eam dislocatio, et est illud os quod iam eminet.	And sometimes a herniation occurs at the end of the spondylos of the back; and it is thought to be due to a displacement, and that is the bone which projects out.
Quare non oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei cum hac medicina: fortasse enim accidere faciet mortem.	Therefore it is not proper to make an assumption with this medicine; perhaps indeed it will cause death.
¶ De curatione Anchae dislocatae.	¶ Of the cure of a dislocated neck.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter 32.
Scias, quod iuncturae Anchae, et iuncturae humeri, non accidit, nisi dislocatio tantum: neque accidit eis quod accidit reliquis iuncturis ex remotione parua, et concauitate.	You should know that a dislocation of the neck and a dislocation of the shoulder do not occur except by total dislocation; nor do they occur in them what occurs in other joints from slight removal and hollows.
Et iunctura quidem Anchae dislocatur secundum quatuor partes.	And indeed the joint of the neck is dislocated according to four parts.De prima parte dislocationis Anchae dicemus, quando dislocatur.
Quod est, quia dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	Of the first part of a dislocation of the neck we will say when it is dislocated.That is, because it is dislocated towards the front and towards the back.Et prima dislocatio est, ut accidat ad posteriora: secunda autem ad anteriora.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur ad interiora: et parum dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	And it is very frequently dislocated inward; and seldom dislocated either in front or behind.
Et curatio dislocationis eius ad interiora, est: quia quando tu coniungis crus infirmi sanum cum infirmo, est longius: et est genu eius eminens plus quam sani, et non potest infirmus duplicare pedem suum apud inguen: et est locus qui sequitur inguen apostematus apostemate calido, propterea, quod caput coxae iam peruenit illic.	And the cure of its dislocation towards the interior is to be applied; for when you join the sick shin with the sound one, the former is longer, and the knee of it projects more than that of the sound one: and the sick person cannot double his foot upon his thigh: and there is a place which follows after the thigh swollen with a hot swelling because the head of the hip has already come to that place.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad exteriora est, quod sunt accidentia eius contraria istis accidentibus.	And the sign by which we know it is dislocated outward is that there are accidents contrary to those named.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad anteriora, est, quia expandit crus sanum secundum complementum: uerumtamen non duplicat ipsum absque dolore qui est in genu: et si conatur ad ambulandum, non potest super illud ad anteriora: et retinetur urina eius, et apostematur inguen eius, et apud ambulationem est calcatio eius super calcaneum.	And the sign by which we know it is dislocated before is that he extends his sound shin according to its complement; but he cannot double it without pain in the knee: and if he tries to walk, he cannot go beyond it in front: and his urine is retained, and his thigh is swollen with a swelling, and there is a bruise on his heel when he walks.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad posteriora est, ut non expandat genu, neque possit duplicare ipsum antequam duplicet inguen: et est crus eius etiam breuius altero: et inguen est mollificatum, et est caput coxae apud locum ilii.	And the sign by which we know it is dislocated behind is that he cannot extend his knee nor can he double up his shin before he doubles up his thigh; and his shin also is shorter than the other: and his thigh is relaxed, and the head of the hip is in the place of the buttock.
Reductio uero huius dislocationis specierum est, ut consyderes tunc, si dislocatio est uetusta, quae iam antiquatur cum habente ipsam.	The reduction however of this dislocation is different according to the species: you ought then to consider, when it is an old dislocation, which has already become ancient with the patient.
Deinde si tu administres reductionem eius, et remanet secundum dispositionem suam: tunc non est in ea curatio omnino.	Then if you effect its reduction and it remains as before; then there is no cure at all.Et si remansit, sed non secundum dispositionem suam, sed iterat ad anteriora uel posteriora et interiora: et hoc ostenditur secundum locum apostematis et urinarum retentionem.
Non ergo oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei penitus.	And if it remains but not as before; and recurs to the front or behind or within: and this is seen according to the place of the swelling and of the retention of urine.It must not then be supposed that it is cured entirely.
In illo autem cuius dislocatio est recens, et est ex una specierum quatuor dislocationis: tunc propera ad hoc, ut uoluas iuncturam, et extendas ipsam ad interiora et ad exteriora, et moueas eam dextra et sinistra: fortasse enim redit, et non indiget alia cura.	But in him whose dislocation is recent; and it belongs to one of the four species of dislocation: then proceed at once to loosen the joint, and extend it towards within and without, and move it to the right and left; for perhaps it will return, and it will not need any other cure.
Si autem non redit hoc modo, tunc oportet, ut praepares ministrum fortem, et extendat crus eius ab inferiori parte: aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento, quod ligetur super crus eius supra genu: et minister alius extendat manum eius desuper, ita ut intromittat manus suas sub titillicis eius.	If he does not return in this way, then you must have a strong assistant, and extend his leg from the lower part: either with his hands or with a bandage, which is bound above his leg above the knee; and another assistant extends his hand from above, so that he inserts his hands under his armpits.
Deinde stringat cum ligamento leni super radicem coxae, et teneat extremitatem ligamenti alterius.	Then tighten it with a soft bandage over the hip joint and hold the end of the bandage in the other hand.
Et sit extensio eius aut ab anteriori parte inguinis ad partem furculae, aut a posteriori ad partem dorsi.	And the extension is either from the front of the groin to the armpit, or from behind to the back.
Et sit extensio eorum omnium uice una, donec eleuetur infirmus cum corpore suo a terra, et remaneat pendens.	And all their extensions are at once, until the sick person is lifted with his body from the ground and remains hanging.
Et haec enim species extensionis est species communis specierum quatuor.	And this kind of extension is a common type of four types.Sed si non possit elevari infirmus cum corpore suo uel conuersus, sed debet in parte extendere membra sua, ut non sit superi usque ad extremitatem, et alius minister teneat eum per titillicos.
Si ergo redit dislocatio cum eo quod diximus, est bonum: et si non, tunc necesse est omni speciei illud quod dicam de curatione propria.	But if the dislocation does not return with it as we have said, then it is necessary to do what I will say about proper treatment for each type.In his book Albucasis goes on to describe four types of dislocation and their treatments.
In reductione quidem eius propria quando dislocatio est ad interiora, oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super latus suum sanum.	In the proper reduction when the dislocation is inward, the sick person must be laid on his healthy side.Et ponatur sub Titillicis pedis eius super quod dislocata est, uel supra Titillicos, quicunque teneat eum per titillicos et in parte dislocata ponat pedem eius dislocatum in loco suo.
Deinde ponat ligamentum super radicem coxae, in eo quod est inter caput coxae, et locum qui est sub inguine.	Then one should cut the tendon above the root of the hip, where it is between the head of the hip and the place that is under the groin.
Deinde extende ligamentum ad sursum a parte inguinis ad altiorem partem corporis, ad partem furculae.	Then extend the tendon upward from the part of the groin to the higher part of the body, to the part of the fork.
Deinde accipiat minister alius fortis brachia eius, et minuat locum grossum coxae infirmae, et extendat ad exteriora extensione uehementi.	Then another strong assistant should seize his arm and lessen the thick place of the feeble hip, and extend it outward with a vigorous extension.
Iam enim redit ad locum suum.	For now he has returned to his place.
Et haec species est facilioris reliquis speciebus curationis, qua reducitur hoc membrum.	And this is the kind that is easier for the other kinds of treatment by which this limb is reduced.
Si autem excusatur super te, et non obedit tibi ad introitum cum hac specie curationis omnino: tunc oportet, ut ligentur duo pedes infirmi simul cum ligamento forti, leni, super duos calcaneos, et super duo genua: et sit longitudo cuiusque a compare suo quantitatis quatuor digitorum: et sit crus infirmum extensum plus altero quantitate duorum digitorum.	But if he refuses to come to you and does not obey you at all with this kind of treatment: then it is necessary that both feet of the cripple be bound together with a strong, soft tendon, above two heels and over two knees; and let the length of each from its companion be four finger quantities: and let the feeble leg be extended more than two fingers' quantity.
Deinde suspendatur infirmus super caput ligni, quod sit in domo: et sit longitudo eius a terra quantitas duorum brachiorum.	Then the cripple should be suspended over the head of the wood, which is in the house; and let its length from the earth be two arms' quantity.Et ligatur eidem super radicem coxae, ubi sunt duo ligamina ligata.
Deinde praecipe iuueni forti, ut muniat caput coxae: et suspendatur cum infirmo inuenis alius: et impellat iuuenis alius, muniens coxam cum fortitudine, nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then command a strong youth to protect the head of the hip; and let another suspend with the cripple; and one youth should push the other, who protects the hip with strength, for the joint returns to its place with speed.Et postea ligentur pedes simul cum crure: et rediamus in domum.
In reditione autem eius propria, quando est dislocatio ad exteriora, oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super podium, secundum quod narrauimus in habente gibbositatem.	And afterwards the feet are bound together with the thigh; and we return to the house.But in its proper return, when it is a dislocation outward, it is necessary that the cripple lie on a couch, according as we have narrated in having the humpback.Et si excusatur ob eam rem, ut redierit ad locum suum, oportet, ut ligentur pedes simul cum crure, et ligetur super caput coxae: et sit ligamen secundum modum, quod praecepimus in curando dislocationem.
Et stringatur ligamentum super crus eius, infirmum proprie, et super pectus eius.	And tie the bandage over his thigh, the weak one, and over his chest.
Deinde ponantur duo ligna, unum apud pedes eius, et alterum apud caput ipsius.	Then place two sticks, one at his feet and the other at his head.
Deinde ponatur lignum additum in medio podii, fixum bene: super quod inuoluti sint panni humidi, ut non laedat infirmum: et sit lignum inter coxas eius, ut non attrahatur ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then place an additional board in the middle of the stretcher, firmly fixed: over which are wound moistened sheets, so that it does not injure the invalid; and let there be a board between his thighs, so that he is not drawn down to the lower part when being extended.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem suam, et medicus aequet reductionem manu sua.	Then every assistant should take hold of his side, and the doctor with his hand effect an equal reduction.
Si ergo obedit ad reuersionem, erit bonum.	If therefore he yields to being reduced, that will be good.Et si non obeiat sese extendi: medicus iterum intenderit manibus suis contraria, et ministeris inuertendis eum per somnum trahat: et iterum extendatur.
Et si non, pone super ipsam tabulam, et preme ipsam, sicut diximus in gibbositate, aequaliter.	And if not, place a board over it and press on it equally as we have said about humps.Then the doctor with his hands should try to reduce him by pulling towards himself.
Verumtamen oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	However, the invalid must lie on his sound side.Et si per somnum non obeiat sese extendere, minister ab imo pedum trahat ad summum caput.
Et quando dislocatio est ad anteriora, tunc oportet, ut extendatur crus infirmi uelociter: et est secundum hanc eandem narrationem super podium: et ponat medicus palmam manus suae dextrae super inguen infirmum.	And when the dislocation is towards the front, then the invalid's weak leg must be extended quickly; and it is according to this same account on the stretcher; and the doctor should place the palm of his right hand over the invalid's hip.Et trahat minister ab imo pedum ad summum caput, cum uelocitate, sicut diximus super podium: et iterum ponatur super pectus infirmum ligatura: et erunt duo ligna apud pedes et caput eius in locis suis.
Deinde coartet ipsum cum manu altera, et cum illa coartatione pone ipsum extensum ad inferiora ad partem genu.	Then the assistant should pull from the invalid's feet to his head quickly as we have said about the stretcher; and then the bandage is put over the invalid's chest again; and there will be two sticks at his feet and at his head in their places.Then with his other hand he should draw the invalid towards himself with that contraction, and with that drawing place him extended towards the lower part at the knee joint.
